description: The Prophet Muhammad sets out toward Mecca with the army that captures it bloodlessly.

The International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature establish the "starting point" for standardized species names across the animal kingdom, based on the binomial nomenclature by Carolus Linnaeus 10th edition of Systema Naturae
Emancipation Proclamation issued by Abraham Lincoln to free slaves in US confederate states
German physicist Wilhelm Röntgen announces his discovery of x-rays
European Economic Community, better known as the European Common Market starts operation
The Alamanni cross the frozen Rhine River in large numbers, invading the Roman Empire
Muhammad XII. (Boabdil) last Nasird ruler of Moorish fortress Alhambra surrenders to the Catholic Monarchs
Tsar Ivan the Terrible's march to Novgorod begins
American anarcho-syndicalist union known as the Industrial Workers of the World forms
World War II: the 28 nations at war with Axis powers pledge to make no separate peace deals
Mahatma Gandhi begins march for peace in East-Bengali
Leonardo da Vinci unsuccessfully tests a flying machine.
Martin Luther excommunicated by Pope Leo X from the Roman Catholic Church
General George Washington's revolutionary army defeats British forces at Battle of Princeton, NJ
Benito Mussolini dissolves Italian parliament/becomes dictator
Apple Computer, Inc incorporates
Israel government confirms resettlement of 10,000 Ethiopian Jews
Samuel Colt sells his first revolver pistol to the United States government
The New York Stock Exchange opens its first permanent headquarters at 10-12 Broad near Wall Street in New York City.
Billboard magazine publishes its 1st music hit parade
Luna 1 (Mechta) becomes 1st craft to leave Earth's gravity
Longest recorded strike ends-33 yrs-Danish barbers' assistants
Battle of Nancy, Burgundy vs Switzerland, 7,000 + killed including their leader Charles Duke of Burgundy
British naval expedition led by Benedict Arnold burns Richmond, Virginia
National Socialist Party (Nazi) forms as German Farmers' Party
Mao Zedong writes "A Single Spark Can Start a Prairie Fire"
US President Harry Truman labels his administration the "Fair Deal"
The first edition of El ingenioso hidalgo Don Quijote de la Mancha (Book One of Don Quixote) by Miguel de Cervantes is published in Madrid.
The English Rump Parliament votes to put Charles I on trial for treason and other "high crimes"
1st recorded boxing match (Duke of Albemarle's butler vs his butcher)

Alfred Wegener, geophysicist and meteorologist, presents his controversial theory of continental drift in a lecture at a the Geological Association (Geologischen Vereinigung) at the Senckenberg-Museum, Frankfurt.
President Franklin Roosevelt's "4 Freedoms" speech (freedom of speech and worship; freedom from want and fear) during US State of Union address
Astronomers at University of California see 1st sight of birth of a galaxy
Galileo discovers first three satellites of Jupiter, Io, Europa & Ganymede
Typewriter patented by Englishman Henry Mill (built years later)
US President Harry Truman announces American development of the hydrogen bomb
Georgetown-IBM experiment, 1st public demonstration of a machine translation system, is held at IBM's head office in New York
Impeachment trial of President Bill Clinton begins in the US Senate.
Oldest surviving commercial newspaper begins (Haarlem, Netherlands)
1st US President George Washington delivers 1st state of the union address
The United States national debt is 0 for the first and only time.

Chiefs, representatives of people's and church organisations, and other prominent individuals form the African National Congress and declare its aim to bring all Africans together as one people to defend their rights and freedoms
WWI: ANZAC forces withdraw from the Gallipoli Peninsula after Ottoman forces successfully defend access to Constantinople
Abdulaziz Ibn Saud becomes King of Nejd and Hejaz; forerunner of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
Judges' investigations for the trial of Joan of Arc begin in Rouen, France, the seat of the English occupation government.
Afghans defeat Marathas in battle of Barari Ghat
Daguerrotype photo process announced at French Academy of Science
Ernest Shackleton as part of the British Nimrod Expedition reaches a record farthest South latitude (88°23' south)
6,000 Jews exterminated in pogrom in Bucharest, Romania
Apple Inc CEO Steve Jobs announces the iPhone
Order of Golden Fleece established in Austria-Hungary & Spain
Stephen III of Moldavia defeats the Ottoman Empire at the Battle of Vaslui.
"Common Sense" Pamphlet by Thomas Paine, published advocating American independence
Tea from India 1st arrives in UK
UN General Assembly meets for 1st time in London
Jacob van Necks fleet leaves Bantam Java with pepper, clove & muskaat
1st pineapples planted in Hawaii (or 1/21)
First public demonstration of telegraph message sent using dots & dashes at Speedwell Ironworks, Morristown, New Jersey by Samuel Morse and Alfred Vail
Insulin first used on humans to treat diabetes, on Leonard Thompson, 14, of Canada
1st government report warning by US Surgeon General Luther Terry that smoking may be hazardous
Gustav I of Sweden "father of the nation" crowned King of Sweden. Rules 37 years
Bayinnaung is crowned King of Burma. He would go on to assemble the largest empire in the history of Southeast Asia
Yohannes IV is crowned Emperor of Ethiopia in Axum, the first imperial coronation in that city in over 200 years.
Mahatma Gandhi begins his final fast
Nigerian civil war ends, Biafra surrenders to Nigeria
Earthquake occurs in Haiti killing 230,000 and destroying the majority of the capital Port-au-Prince
Nika riots begin in Contaninople, revolt against Emperor Justinian, prompted by chariot racing
John Walter publishes 1st issue of "The Times" of London
National Geographic Society founded in Washington, D.C.
Telimco makes the 1st ever advertisment for a radio set, by advertising a $7.50 set in the "Scientific American" which claimed to receive signals for up to one mile
Hitler declares "Total War"
Microsoft chairman Bill Gates steps aside as chief executive and promotes company president Steve Ballmer to the position
Charles V and Francis I sign the Treaty of Madrid, forcing Francis to give up claims to Burgundy, Italy and Flanders
United East Indian Company conquers city of Malacca, 7,000 killed
US Revolutionary War ends with the US Congress of the Confederation ratifying the Treaty of Paris
Tunisian president Ben Ali, flees to Saudi Arabia after popular protests known as the Jasmine Revolution
Henry VIII declares himself head of the Church in England
Elizabeth I crowned Queen of England in Westminster Abbey
British Museum opens in Montague House, London
Tchaikovsky's ballet "Swan Lake" premieres, St Petersburg (1/27 NS)
Wikipedia a free Wiki content encyclopedia is launched by Jimmy Wales and Larry Sanger
The Medici family is appointed official banker of the Papacy
Ivan IV the Terrible (17) crowns himself first tsar of Moscow
French King Louis XVI sentenced to death by the National Convention during the French Revolution
British House of Commons accepts Home Rule for Ireland (but the Great War gets in the way of it happening)
1st assembly of the League of Nations is held in Paris
Captain James Cook becomes 1st to cross Antarctic Circle (66° 33' S)
A group of Modoc warriors defeats the United States Army in the First Battle of the Stronghold, a part of the Modoc War.
Captain Robert Scott's expedition arrives at the South Pole, one month after Roald Amundsen
Kuomintang forces under orders from Chiang Kai-shek open fire at communist forces, resuming the Chinese Civil War after World War II
United Nations Security Council holds its 1st meeting
Operation Desert Storm begins, with US-led coalition forces bombing Iraq, during the Gulf War
Nika uprising against Emperor Justinian in Constantinople fails, 30,000 killed by troops loyal to the Emperor in the Hippodrome
King Naresuan of Siam kills Crown Prince Minchit Sra of Burma in single combat, date is now observed as Royal Thai Armed Forces day
First elements of the First Fleet carrying 736 convicts from England to Australia arrives at Botany Bay to set up a penal colony
José de San Martín leads a revolutionary army over the Andes to attack Spanish royalists in Chile
Second German Empire proclaimed by Kaiser Wilhelm I and Otto von Bismarck
Soviets announce they have broken the long siege of Leningrad by Nazi Germany
Theodosius installed as co-emperor of the Eastern Roman Empire
Peninsular War: After a ten day siege, Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington, orders British soldiers of the Light and third divisions to storm Ciudad Rodrigo
The first electric lighting system employing overhead wires, built by Thomas Edison, begins service at Roselle, New Jersey
Indira Gandhi elected India's 4th Prime Minister
Calcium deposits are discovered on Mars by NASA’s Curiosity Rover
First English Parliament summoned other than by royal command (in this instance by Simon de Montfort, Earl of Leicester) mets in Westminster Hall
China cedes Hong Kong to the British during the 1st Opium War
Republic of Turkey declared out of remnants of Ottoman Empire
Nazi officials hold notorious Wannsee conference in Berlin to organise the "final solution", the extermination of Europe's Jews
Franklin D. Roosevelt sworn-in for an unprecedented (and never to be repeated) 4th term as US President
Ronald Reagan inaugurated as the 40th President of the United States of America
Barack Obama, inaugurated as the 44th President of the United States of America, becomes the United States' first African-American president

The Swiss Anabaptist Movement is born when Conrad Grebel, Felix Manz, George Blaurock, and a dozen others baptize each other in the home of Manz's mother in Zürich, breaking a thousand-year tradition of church-state union
Louis XVI of France is executed by the guillotine in Paris, following his conviction for high treason
The Battle of Khe Sanh - one of the most publicized and controversial battles of the Vietnam War - begins at the Khe Sanh Air Base
Black Monday in worldwide stock markets. FTSE 100 had its biggest ever one-day points fall, European stocks closed with their worst result since 9/11, and Asian stocks drop as much as 15%.
Prince William of Orange (future King William III of Britain), summons Convention Parliament to discuss ruling jointly with his wife Mary (daughter of exiled King James II)
Battle of Rorke's Drift: British garrison of 150 holds off 3,000-4,000 Zulu warriors. Eleven Victoria Crosses and a number of other decorations were awarded to the defenders.

In St Petersburg, Russia, a large demonstration of workers led by Father Gapon, march to the Winter Palace with a petition to the Tsar; troops fire on protesters in what becomes known as 'Bloody Sunday'
US president Harry Truman sets up the Central Intelligence Agency
Roe vs Wade: US Supreme Court legalizes most abortions

War elephant corps of the Southern Han defeated at Shao by crossbow fire from Song Dynasty troops; Southern Han state forced to submit to the Song Dynasty. 1st regular war elephant corps in Chinese army
In a coronation ceremony, Zhu Yuanzhang ascends to the throne of China as the Hongwu Emperor, initiating Ming Dynasty rule over China that would last for three centuries.
Shaanxi Earthquake - deadliest ever recorded kills 830,000 in Shensi Province, China
Israeli Knesset resolves Jerusalem is capital of Israel
US President Richard Nixon announces an accord has been reached to end Vietnam War
Sweden becomes the first nation in the world to ban aerosol sprays, believed to be damaging to earth's ozone layer.
Claudius succeeds his nephew Caligula as Roman Emperor after the later's assassination by officers of the Praetorian Guard
University of Calcutta founded as the first full-fledged university in South Asia
Rubber heel for boots or shoes patented by American Humphrey O'Sullivan
Lieutenant General Robert Baden-Powell publishes "Scouting for Boys" as a manual for self-instruction in outdoor skills and self-improvement. The book becomes the inspiration for the Scout Movement.
Apple Computer Inc unveils its revolutionary Macintosh personal computer
Founding of the city of São Paulo in Brazil
Battle at Talikota India: Deccan sultanate destroy Vijayanagar's army and the last Hindu kingdom of Southern India
American naval expedition under Charles Wilkes is first to identify Antarctica as a new continent
1st Israeli election won by David Ben-Gurion's Mapai party
Military coup in Uganda under Major General Idi Amin
Egyptian Revolution of  begins with a series of street demonstrations, rallies, acts of civil disobedience, labor strikes and violent clashes in Cairo, Alexandria and other major cities
"Pentateuch" the Jewish Bible is 1st printed as a book in Bologna, Italy
Lisbon hit by Earthquake; about 30,000 die
The Council of Trent issued its conclusions in the Tridentinum, establishing a distinction between Roman Catholicism and Protestantism
Captain Arthur Phillip and British colonists hoist the Union Flag at Sydney Cove, New South Wales, now celebrated as Australia Day
John Logie Baird gives the first public demonstration of television in his laboratory in London
President Bill Clinton says "I want to say one thing to the American people; I did not have sexual relations with that woman, Miss Lewinsky"
Rashidun Caliphate, then the largest empire in history, ends with death of Ali. Succeeded by the Umayyad Caliphate
U.S. Congress approves Indian Territory (in what is present-day Oklahoma), clearing the way for forced relocation of the Eastern Indians on the "Trail of Tears"
Lenin placed in Mausoleum in Red Square, Moscow
Leningrad liberated from Germany in 880 days with the loss of 600,000 killed
Soviet troops liberate Auschwitz and Birkenau Concentration Camps in Poland
US & North Vietnam's William Rogers & Nguyen Duy Trinh sign cease-fire, ending longest US war and miltary draft
Emperor Charles V opens the Diet of Worms in Worms, Germany which lasts until May 25th. Produced the "Edict of Worms" which dennouced Martin Luther
London's Pall Mall is 1st street lit by gaslight
Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice" is published by Thomas Egerton in the United Kingdom.
Sir Stamford Raffles lands in Singapore
The name "Pakistan" is coined by Choudhry Rahmat Ali and gradually accepted by Muslims in the Indian sub-continent who use it to push for a separate Muslim homeland in South Asia
William Shakespeare's play Romeo and Juliet is thought to have been first performed. Officially published early 1597.
1st successful gasoline powered car patented by Karl Benz in Karlsruhe, Germany
The Coca-Cola Company, is incorporated in Atlanta, Georgia
Emile Grubbe is the first doctor to use radiation treatment for breast cancer
US President George W. Bush in his State of the Union address describes "regimes that sponsor terror" an "Axis of Evil", which includes Iraq, Iran and North Korea
Oliver Cromwell, Lord Protector of the Commonwealth of England is ritually executed after having been dead for two years
Burned US Library of Congress re-established with Thomas Jefferson's 6,500 volumes
President Paul von Hindenburg appoints Adolf Hitler as Reich Chancellor of Germany who forms a government with Franz von Papen
Hitler threatens the Jews during his speech to the German Reichstag (Parliament)
Mahatma Gandhi assassinated by Nathuram Godse
State funeral of Winston Churchill at St Paul's Cathedral in London. Largest ever state funeral.
Congress passes the 13th Amendment, abolishing slavery in America (passes 121-24)
General Robert E Lee named Commander-in-Chief of Confederate Armies during US Civil War
General Friedrich von Paul surrenders to Soviet troops at Stalingrad
US President Harry Truman publicly announces support for the development of a hydrogen bomb
South African President PW Botha offers to free Nelson Mandela if he denounces violence
Queen Elizabeth I of England signs death warrant for her cousin, Mary Stuart, Queen of Scots
1st volume of the Oxford English Dictionary, A-Ant, published
King Carlos I of Portugal and his heir, Prince Luis Filipe are assassinated by Republican sympathizers in Terreiro do Paco, Lisbon
Saigon police chief Nguyễn Ngọc Loan executes Viet Cong officer Nguyễn Văn Lém with a pistol shot to head. The execution is captured by photographer Eddie Adams and becomes an anti-war icon.
Ayatollah Khomeini returns to Iran after 15 years in exile
Space Shuttle Columbia disintegrates during reentry into the Earth's atmosphere, killing all seven astronauts aboard.
New Amsterdam becomes a city (later renamed New York)
Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo ends the Mexican-American War: US acquires Texas, California, New Mexico and Arizona for $15 million
Queen Victoria's funeral takes place in St. George's Chapel
James Joyce's "Ulysses" published in Paris (1,000 copies)
German 6th Army surrenders after Battle of Stalingrad in a major turning point in Europe during World War II
Idi Amin ousts Milton Obote and appoints himself President (dictator) of Uganda
Sultan Mehmed II, the Conqueror inherits the throne of the Ottoman Empire
US state of Iowa ratifies the 15th Amendment of the United States Constitution allowing suffrage for all races & colour
1st soft landing on Moon (Soviet Luna 9)
Roman Emperor Septimius Severus dies, leaving the Roman Empire in the hands of his two quarrelsome sons, Caracalla and Geta
Coronation of Zhao Kuangyin as Emperor Taizu of the Song, initiating three centuries of Song Dynasty dominance in southern China
1st US electoral college chooses George Washington as President and John Adams as Vice-President
The Codex Sinaiticus is discovered in Egypt.
Robert E. Lee is named general-in-chief of Confederate forces
The Palestine National Congress appoints Yasser Arafat chairman of the PLO
Panamanian General Manuel Noriega indicted by US federal grand jury for drug trafficking and racketeering
Henry of Navarre (later Henry IV of France) abjures Catholicism at Tours
News of the fall of Khartoum reaches London
King Leopold II of Belgium establishes the Congo as a personal colonial possession
"Modern Times", directed by, written by and starring Charlie Chaplin, is released
Maximilian I proclaimed Holy Roman Emperor,though 1st Emperor in centuries not to be crowned by the Pope
France recognizes USA, signs Treaty of Alliance in Paris the 1st US treaty
Stamford Raffles founds Singapore as a British trading port
Queen Elizabeth II succeeds King George VI to the British throne and proclaimed Queen of the United Kingdom and the other Commonwealth realms including Canada, Australia and New Zealand
Solidarity union leader Lech Wałęsa begins negotiating with Polish government
The Mongols burn the Russian city of Vladimir
Edward of Caernarion (later Edward II) becomes first (English) Prince of Wales
Battle of Debre Tabor: Ras Ali Alula, Regent of the Emperor of Ethiopia defeats warlord Wube Haile Maryam of Semien.
The colonial Tasmanian Parliament passes the first piece of legislation (the Electoral Act of ) anywhere in the world providing for elections by way of a secret ballot.
The IRA launches a mortar attack on 10 Downing Street during a cabinet meeting.
Isaac Newton reads 1st optics paper before Royal Society in London
Battle of Eylau ends inconclusively between Napoleon's forces and Russian Empire - 1st battle Napoleon isn't victorious
"The Birth of a Nation" the first 12-reel film in America, directed by D. W. Griffith, starring Lillian Gish and Mae Marsh, opens at Clune's Auditorium in Los Angeles

Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom issued an Order-in-Council, stating that she and her family would be known as the House of Windsor, and that her descendants will take the name "Mountbatten-Windsor".
Nasdaq Composite stock market index debuts with 50 companies and a starting value of 100
100, 000 people march to demand justice for the atrocities of the Bangladesh Liberation War in Dhaka
Zeno crowned as co-emperor of the Byzantine Empire together with his son Leo II.
British Parliament declares Massachusetts colony is in rebellion
Japanese land troops at Chemulpo (Inchon), near Seoul, Korea; within the next three weeks they will have advanced to the Yalu River, border of Manchuria
Japanese troops evacuate Guadalcanal, ends epic WWII battle on the Solomon Islands in the Pacific
British government declares state of emergency after month-long coal miners' strike
St Paul thought to have been shipwrecked at Malta
Edmond Halley appointed as the second Astronomer Royal at the Greenwich Observatory
Treaty of Paris ends French-Indian War, surrendering Canada to Britain
Simón Bolívar named dictator by the Congress of Peru
Henry Morton Stanley departs for the Congo
British battleship HMS Dreadnought launched after only 100 days, rendering all other capital ships obsolete with its revolutionary design
IBM computer Deep Blue becomes the first computer to win a game of chess against a reigning (human) chess champion, Gary Kasparov
Henry VIII recognised as supreme head of Church in England following the schism with Rome
First vision of the Virgin Mary to 14-year-old Bernadette of Lourdes, France
Vatican City (world's smallest country) made an enclave of Rome
Margaret Thatcher defeats Edward Heath for leadership of the British Conservative Party
Nelson Mandela released after 27 years imprisonment in South Africa
Egyptian Revolution culminates in the resignation of Hosni Mubarak and the transfer of power to the Supreme Military Council after 18 days of protests.
Pope Benedict XVI announces his resignation from February 28, the first pope to resign since 1415
The Great Northern War begins in Northern Europe between Denmark–Norway, Saxony and Russia and the Swedish Empire.
Last Ch'ing (Manchu) emperor of China, Hsuan T'ung, abdicates
US President Bill Clinton acquitted by the Senate in his impeachment trial
NEAR Shoemaker spacecraft touchdown in the "saddle" region of 433 Eros becoming the first spacecraft to land on an asteroid.
North Korea confirms it has successfully tested a nuclear device that could be weaponized
Baghdad falls to the Mongols as the Abbasid Caliphate is destroyed
1st British East India Company voyage departs from London, lead by John Lancaster
British Parliament adopts the Bill of Rights which establishes the rights of parliament and places limits on the crown
Hitler's Operation Sealion, the invasion of England, is cancelled
Allied planes begin bombing Dresden, Germany; a firestorm results and over 22,000 die
USSR captures Budapest, after a 49-day battle with Germany; 159,000 die
Pope Benedict VIII crowns Henry II Roman German Emperor
Pope Gregory VII excommunicates Holy Roman Emperor Henry IV (for the 1st time)

The Battle of Cape St Vincent: British fleet under Admiral Sir John Jervis defeats larger Spanish fleet under Admiral Don José de Córdoba y Ramos near Cape St. Vincent, Portugal. Captain Horatio Nelson distinguishes himself.
A G Bell & Elisha Gray apply separately for telephone patents Supreme Court eventually rules Bell rightful inventor
St Valentine's Day Massacre in Chicago, 7 gangsters killed, allegedly on Al Capone's orders
Richard Nixon installs secret taping system in the White House
Khosrau II, the last great Sasanian king is crowned King of Persia
Austria, Prussia & Saxony sign Treaty of Hubertusburg, marking the end of the French and Indian War and of the Seven Years War
Ferdinand Marcos wins rigged presidential election in the Philippines
First draft of the complete human genome is published in the journal "Nature"
An estimated 6-11 million people around the world take to the streets to protest against war with Iraq
1st known cheque (£400) (on display at Westminster Abbey)
American Charles Wilkes discovers Shackleton Ice Shelf, Antarctica
Howard Carter opens the inner burial chamber of the Pharaoh Tutankhamun's tomb and finds the sarcophagus
Fidel Castro becomes the 16th Prime Minister of Cuba after overthrowing Fulgencio Batista
The Kyoto Protocol comes into force following its ratification by Russia.
Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian II agrees to pay tribute to the Ottoman Empire for peace
Columbia, South Carolina, burns down during American Civil War
Sardines first canned by Julius Wolff in Eastport, Maine
Golda Meir sworn in as the first female Prime Minister of Israel
British Parliament votes to join the European Common Market
Henry Tudor (later Henry VIII) created Prince of Wales
John Bunyan's "Pilgrim's Progress" is published in Holborn, London, by Nathaniel Ponder
King Victor Emmanuel II of Sardinia becomes first King of Italy
Mark Twain publishes the "Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" in the US
The first Academy Awards are announced

Ukrainian Revolution of  begins as protesters, riot police and unknown shooters take part in violent events in the capital, Kiev, culminating after five days in the ouster of President Viktor Yanukovych
Emperor Constantius II shuts all heathen temples
Russian Tsar Alexander II abolishes serfdom [NS=Mar 3]
Thomas Edison patents the gramophone (phonograph)
About 150 Japanese warplanes attack the Australian city of Darwin
US 5th Fleet launches invasion of Iwo Jima against the Japanese with 30,000 US Marines
US postal service created, postage 6-12 cents depending on distance
Rossini's opera "Barber of Seville" premieres in Rome
New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art opens
British Naval Officer John Morseby discovers the site of Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea and claims it for Britain
UK Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden resigns stating Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain has appeased Nazi Germany
Earl Mountbatten of Burma appointed as last viceroy of India to oversee the move to independence.
Pope Alexander III canonizes Thomas Becket, Archbishop of Canterbury
Joan of Arc's first day of interrogation during her trial for heresy
Michael Romanov, son of Patriarch of Moscow, elected first Russian Tsar of the house of Romanov
1st locomotive, Richard Trevithick's, runs for the 1st time, along the tramway of the Penydarren Ironworks in Merthyr Tydfil, Wales
World War I: Battle of Verdun begins, leads to an estimated 1 million casualties
Britain declares Egypt a sovereign state
Francis Crick and James Watson discover structure of DNA-molecule
Galileo's Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems is published.
British House of Lords rules authors do not have perpetual copyright
The Last Invasion of Britain by the French, begins near Fishguard, Wales
Russia & Britain establish Alaska-Canada boundary
25,000 US & South Vietnamese troops launch Operation Junction City against Viet Cong. Largest US airborne assult since WWII
Roman Emperor Diocletian begins his policy of persecuting Christians, razing the church at Nicomedia
Johannes Gutenberg prints his first Bible (estimated date)
Francisco Vázquez de Coronado's expedition sets off from Mexico in search of the 7 cities of Cibola
Alamo besieged for 13 days until March 6 by Mexican army under General Santa Anna; entire garrison eventually killed
United States acquires control of the Panama Canal Zone for $10 million
US Marines raise the flag on Iwo Jima, later a famous photo and Marine Corps War Memorial sculpture
Osama bin Laden publishes a fatwa declaring jihad against all Jews and Crusaders.
1st official Roman edict for persecution of Christians issued by Emperor Diocletian
Battle of Pavia: Holy Roman Emperor Charles V's troops beat the French. French King Francois I captured, 15,000 killed/wounded
Pope Gregory XIII announces New Style (Gregorian) calendar
Battle of Karnal: Army of Iranian ruler Nadir Shah defeats the forces of the Mughal emperor of India, Muhammad Shah

Agustín de Iturbide and Vicente Guerrero agree to the Plan of Iguala, stating that Mexico will become a constitutional monarchy, Roman Catholicism the official religion and that Peninsulares and Creoles will enjoy equal political and social rights
US House of Representatives vote 126 to 47 to impeach President Andrew Johnson
General Juan Perón first elected President of Argentina
Fidel Castro retires as the President of Cuba due to ill health after nearly fifty years
Pius V excommunicates Queen Elizabeth I of England and absolves her subjects from allegiance to the crown
1st US cabinet meeting, held at George Washington's home
Paper currency (greenbacks) introduced in US by President Abraham Lincoln
Dalai Lama flees Tibet for British India to escape Chinese troops
Nikita Khrushchev denounces Joseph Stalin at the 20th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union
Roman Inquisition delivers injunction to Galileo demanding he abandon his belief in heliocentrism
Bank of England issues first £1 note
Napoleon Bonaparte and his supporters leave Elba to start a 100 day re-conquest of France
Berlin Conference gives Congo to Belgium and Nigeria to Great Britain
Hosni Mubarak, President of Egypt, orders the constitution changed to allow multi-candidate presidential elections, asking Egyptian parliament to amend Article 76
In London, the Trades Union Congress and the Independent Labour Party (formed in 1893) meet, resulting in a Labour Representative Committee and eventually the modern Labour Party in 1906
Mao's famous speech to the Supreme State Conference "On Correct Handling of Contradictions Among People" expounding Maoist ideals
Robert Mugabe's ZANU-PF wins elections in Zimbabwe
Wikileaks begins disclosing 5 million emails from private intelligence company Stratfor
In the Battle of Helsingborg, 14,000 Danish invaders under Jørgen Rantzau are decisively defeated by an equally sized Swedish force under Magnus Stenbock.
Republican Party formally organized at Ripon, Wisc
WWI: After the French try to drive the Germans forces back into the Champagne region, they gain a few hundred yards - at the cost of 50,000 casualties
228 Incident: In Taiwan, civil disorder is put down with the loss of 30,000 civilian lives.
Gulf War ends after Iraq accepts a ceasefire following their retreat from Kuwait
Georgeana (York) Maine became the 1st incorporated American city
Pennsylvania becomes 1st US state to abolish slavery (for new-borns only)
Michigan becomes 1st English-speaking jurisdiction to abolish the death penalty (except for treason against the state)
Postage stamps showing scenes are issued for 1st time
Yellowstone becomes world's 1st national park
Long-distance communication speeds up with the unveiling of a semaphore machine in Paris.
US Congress bans the slave trade within the US, effective January 1, 1808
The Convention of Constantinople is signed, guaranteeing free maritime passage through the Suez Canal during war and peace.
Ho Chi Minh elected President of North Vietnam
Morocco tears up the Treaty of Fez, declaring independence from France
White government of Rhodesia declares itself a republic
U.S. invasion of Afghanistan: US conventional forces first delpoyed as part of Operation Anaconda
Indian Mughal Emperor Akbar defeats Bengali army at the Battle of Tukaroi
Second Opium War: France and the United Kingdom declare war on China
Alexander II of Russia signs the Emancipation Manifesto, freeing serfs and granted them the full rights of free citizens [OS=Feb 19]
Anne Sullivan begins teaching 6 year old blind-deaf Helen Keller
1st major strike of the Russian "February Revolution" starts at the giatn Putilov factory in Petrograd [OS=Feb 18]
Mahatma Gandhi begins a fast in Mumbai (Bombay) to protest against autocratic rule in India
Battle of the Bismarck Sea: Australian and American air forces devastate Japanese navy convoy
Los Angeles police officers severely beat motorist Rodney King, the beating is famously captured on amateur video and later leads to riots when the police officers are acquitted
Battle of the Sit River: Mongol forces of Batu Khan overcome Russians under Yuri II of Vladimir-Suzdal near Yaroslavl in Russia, ending Russian resistance
Thomas Jefferson is the first US President inaugurated in Washington, D.C.
Abraham Lincoln is inaugurated as the 16th US President
First recorded case of Spanish flu at Funston Army Camp, Kanas; start of worldwide pandemic killing 50-100 million
Franklin D. Roosevelt inaugurated as 32nd US President, pledges to pull US out of the Depression, "We have nothing to fear but fear itself"
1st flight of the airship Hindenburg at Friedrichshafen, Germany

International Criminal Court issues an arrest warrant for Sudanese President Omar Hassan al-Bashir for war crimes and crimes against humanity in Darfur becoming the first sitting head of state to be indicted
Roman Emperor Julian moves from Antioch with an army of 90,000 to attack the Sassanid Empire, in a campaign that brings about his own death
Persian scholar Naser Khosrow begins the 7 year Middle Eastern journey which he will later describe in his book Safarnama
English King Henry VII hands John Cabot (Giovanni Caboto) a commission to explore for new lands

Boston Massacre (Incident on King Street): British soldiers kill 5 men in a crowd throwing snowballs, stones and sticks at them. African American Crispus Attucks 1st to die; later held up as early black martyr. The massacre galvanized anti-British feelings.
Winston Churchill's "Iron Curtain" speech in Fulton, Missouri, popularizes the term and draws attention to the division of Europe
Treaty of Alcaçovas: Portugal gives the Canary Islands to Castile in exchange for claims in West Africa
Battle of the Alamo: After 13 days of fighting 1,500-3,000 Mexican soldiers overwhelm the Texan defenders, killing 182-257 Texans including William Travis, Jim Bowie and Davy Crockett
Giuseppe Verdi's Opera "La Traviata" premieres in Venice
Dred Scott Decision: US Supreme Court rules Africans cannot be US citizens
Dmitri Mendeleev presents the first periodic table of the elements to the Russian Chemical Society
"Aspirin" (acetylsalicylic acid) patented by Felix Hoffmann at German company Bayer
Roman Emperor Antoninus Pius dies and is succeeded by co-Emperors Marcus Aurelius and Lucius Verus, an unprecedented political arrangement in the Roman Empire.
King Henry VIII's divorce request is denied by the Pope. Henry then declares that he, not the Pope, is supreme head of England's church
Alexander Graham Bell patents the telephone
Roald Amundsen announces discovery of the South Pole
Hitler breaks Treaty of Versailles, sends troops to Rhineland
The New York Stock Exchange is founded.
British North America Act is passed in the House of Commons, serves as Canada's constitution for more than 100 years
Russian "February Revolution" begins in earnest with protests celebrating International Woman's Day and riots in St Petersburg over food rations and conduct of the war [OS=Feb 23]
US Supreme Court rules in McCollum v. Board of Education that religious instruction in public schools is unconstitutional

The Provisional Irish Republican Army undertakes its first operation in Great Britain, planting four car bombs in London; 10 members of PIRA are arrested at Heathrow Airport while trying to leave the country
Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 with 239 people loses contact and disappears, prompting the most expensive search effort in history

Martin Luther begins preaching his "Invocavit Sermons" in the German city of Wittenberg, reminding citizens to trust God's word rather than violence and thus helping bring to a close the revolutionary stage of the Reformation
Publication of the influential economics book "The Wealth of Nations" by Adam Smith
Russian Bolshevik Party becomes the Communist Party
US Congress is called into special session by FDR, beginning its "100 days"
Soviet flight Sputnik 9 carries and returns from orbit a dog named Chernushka (Blackie), frogs and a guinea pig
USS Alliance under Captain Barry fights and wins last naval battle of US Revolutionary War off Cape Canaveral
West African political leader El Hadj Umar Tall seizes the city of Segou, destroying the Bambara Empire of Mali
First telephone call; Alexander Graham Bell says "Mr. Watson, come here, I want to see you" to his assistant Thomas Watson
Home Rule Act passed by the British Parliament, dividing Ireland into two parts; it is rejected by the southern counties, where the Ango-Irish war continues for a year
Military coup led by General Fulgencio Batista in Cuba
The NASDAQ Composite stock market index peaks at 5132.52, signalling the beginning of the end of the dot-com boom
Icon veneration officially re-instated in Hagia Sophia Cathedral in Constantinople
Ismail I, founder of the Safavid dynasty, crowned Shah of Persia (rules till 1524)
Moscow becomes capital of revolutionary Russia
Military coup led by Indonesian Gen Suharto breaks out
Mikhail Gorbachev replaces Konstantin Chernenko as Soviet leader
9.0 magnitude earthquake strikes 130 km (80 miles) east of Sendai, Japan, triggering a tsunami killing thousands of people and causing the second worst nuclear accident in history
Witiges, king of the Ostrogoths, ends his siege of Rome and retreats to Ravenna, leaving the city in the hands of the victorious Roman general, Belisarius.
First record of Johannes Gutenberg's Bible, letter dated this day by Enea Silvio Piccolomini refers to the bible printed a year before
Congress accepts Pre-emption Bill: free land in West for colonists
Mohandas Gandhi begins 200m (300km) march protesting British salt tax
Church of England ordains 1st 33 women priests
Battle of Badr: Muhammad's Muslim forces win significant victory over Meccan army
Battle at Tondibi: Moroccan army under Judar defeats Sultan Askia Ishaq II of Songhai
William Herschel sees what he thinks is a "comet" but is actually the discovery of the planet Uranus
Siege of Khartoum, Sudan begins by Mahdist forces, lasts 10 months
Fall of the Sokoto Caliphate in Northern Nigeria, the British claim supremacy of over 500,000 square miles
Clyde Tombaugh announces discovery of Pluto at Lowell Observatory
The journal Nature reports that 350,000-year-old footprints of an upright-walking human have been found in Italy
Battle of Ivry: French King Henry IV beats Catholic League during French Wars of Religion
Eli Whitney patents the cotton gin machine revolutionizing the cotton industry in the southern US states
Hugo de Vries rediscovers Mendel's laws of genetics
US currency goes on gold standard after Congress passes the Currency Act
World War II: Kraków Ghetto is "liquidated"
Xi Jinping is named as the new President of the People's Republic of China
Liu Bei, a Chinese warlord and member of the Han royal house, declares himself Emperor of Shu-Han, claiming legitimate succession to the Han Dynasty
Christopher Columbus returns to Spain after his first voyage to the New World
In an emotional speech in Newburgh, New York, George Washington asks his officers not to support the Newburgh Conspiracy. The plea is successful and the threatened coup d'etat never takes place.
Nicholas II, the last Russian Tsar abdicates and nominates his brother Grand Duke Michael to succeed him [OS Mar 2]
Five research groups announce the discovery of anti-matter
Battle at Khanua: Mughal Emperor Babur beats Rajputen
English Long Parliament disbands
King Gustav III of Sweden is shot by Count Anckarström at a masked ball at the Opera; he dies on March 29.
First publication of an article by Joseph Lister outlining the discovery of antiseptic surgery, in The Lancet.
Adolf Hitler orders German rearmament in violation of The Treaty of Versailles
Saint Patrick, aged about 16 is captured by Irish pirates from his home in Great Britain and taken as a slave to Ireland (traditional date)
Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan reaches the Philippines
Italy is unified into a single kingdom under Victor Emmanuel II following the campaigns led by Giuseppe Garibaldi
At a show in Paris 71 Vincent van Gogh paintings cause a sensation, 11 years after his death
Sino-Japanese War (1937-1945): The Battle of Nanchang between the Kuomintang and the Japanese breaks out.
Bełżec Concentration Camp opens with the transport of 30,000 Lublin Polish Jews
1st Latern Council (9th ecumenical council) opens in Rome, agreements of the Concordat of Worms ratified
Jacques de Molay, the 23rd and the last Grand Master of the Knights Templar, is burned at the stake by King Philip IV of France
According to legend, Tenochtitlan is founded on this date. The event is depicted on the Mexican coat of arms.
Japan uses its influence over Korea to deny Russia's efforts to obtain a naval station at Korean Port of Masampo, the lead up to the Russo-Japanese war
British magistrates in India sentence Mahatma Gandhi to 6 years imprisonment for disobedience
Benito Mussolini joins Hitler in Germany's war against France & Britain
Cosmonaut Aleksei Leonov, leaving his spacecraft Voskhod 2 for 12 minutes, becomes the first person to walk in space.
A Mongolian victory at the naval Battle of Yamen ends the Song Dynasty in China.
200 members of Peking imperial family/court commit suicide in loyalty to the Emperor
US Senate rejects Treaty of Versailles for 2nd time refusing to ratify League of Nations' covenant (maintaining isolation policy)
The Sydney Harbour Bridge is opened.
Invasion of Iraq by American and British led coalition begins without United Nations support and in defiance of world opinion
United Dutch East Indian Company (VOC) forms
Napoleon enters Paris after escape from Elba, begins 100-day rule
German Emperor Wilhelm II fires chancellor Otto von Bismarck
US Secretary of State John Hay announces that all nations to whom he sent notes calling for an 'open door' policy in China have essentially accepted his stand.
Dachau, 1st Nazi concentration camp, completed
Barack Obama becomes the first US President to visit Cuba since 1928, arriving for a 2 day tour
3,000 Jews killed in Black Death riots in Efurt, Germany
Civil Code of Napoleon adopted in France
Journalist Henry Morton Stanley begins his famous expedition to Africa
Ethiopia abolishes its monarchy after 3,000 years
Russia formally annexes Crimea amid international condemenation
First American Indian (Powhattan) massacre of Europeans in Jamestown Virginia, 347 killed
Stamp Act passed; 1st direct British tax on American colonists, organized by Prime Minister George Grenville
The Emerald Buddha is moved with great ceremony to its current place in Wat Phra Kaew, Thailand.
British Parliament, led by Charles Grey, passes the Reform Act, introducing wide-ranging changes to electoral system of England and Wales, increasing electorate from about 500,000 voters to 813,000
1st shopping mall opens in Southfield, Michigan
US confirms its troops used chemical warfare against the Vietcong
1st dated edition of Maimonides "Mishneh Torah", a code of Jewish religious law is published
George Frideric Handel's oratorio "Messiah" premieres in London
Patrick Henry proclaims "Give me liberty or give me death" in speech in favour of Virginian troops joining US Revolutionary war

8th Congress of the Russian Communist Party re-establishes a five-member Politburo which becomes the center of political power in the Soviet Union. Original members Vladimir Lenin, Leon Trotsky, Joseph Stalin, Lev Kamenev and Nikolai Krestinsky
Enabling Act: German Reichstag grants Adolf Hitler dictatorial powers
Largest operation in WWII's Pacific War, 1,500 US Navy ships bomb the Japanese island of Okinawa
Scottish King James VI son of Mary Queen of Scots, becomes King James I of England in succession to Elizabeth I, thus joining the English and Scottish crowns.
Johann Sebastian Bach dedicates his Brandenburg Concertos to Christian Ludwig, Margrave of Brandenburg-Schwedt
Canada gives its black citizens the right to vote
German scientist Robert Koch discovers and describes the tubercle bacillus which causes tuberculosis ( Mycobacterium tuberculosis)
Argentine President Isabel Martínez de Perón is deposed in a military coup
Kosovo War: NATO commences air bombardment against Yugoslavia, marking the first time NATO has attacked a sovereign country.
1st Easter, according to calendar-maker Dionysius Exiguus
Henry Hudson embarks on an exploration for Dutch East India Co
British Parliament abolishes slave trade throughout the British Empire; penalty of £120 per slave introduced for ship captains
Italian troops invade Abyssinia (Ethiopia)
1st guided missile launched from nuclear powered sub (Halibut)
John XIX crowns Conrad II Holy Roman Emperor, founder of the Salian dynasty
Earthquake destroys 90% of Caracas, Venezuela; about 20,000 die
Municipal elections bring revolutionaries to power in Paris to form Commune government
In support of Mohammed Ali Shah's coup d'etat against the constitutional government in Persia, a Russian military force invades northern Persia to relieve the siege of Tabriz
First "Eichmann transport" to Auschwitz & Birkenau concentration camps
Iwo Jima occupied, after 18,000 Japanese & 6,000 Americans killed
Dr Jonas Salk announces vaccine to prevent polio
Large-scale anti-Vietnam War protests take place in the United States, including in New York, Washington D.C. and Chicago
Bangladesh (East Pakistan) under Sheikh Mujibur Rahman declares its independence from Pakistan
Charles I, King Of England, Scotland & Ireland, ascends English throne
1st successful blood transfusion (in Brussels)
Nikita Khrushchev becomes Soviet Premier as well as First Secretary of the Communist Party
Roman Emperor Valentinian I appoints his brother Flavius Valens co-emperor.
Paris is sacked by Viking raiders, probably under Ragnar Lodbrok, who collects a huge ransom in exchange for leaving.
Britain and France declare war on Russia during the Crimean War
Spanish Civil War ends, Madrid falls to Francisco Franco
Cold War: The United States State Department releases the Acheson-Lilienthal Report, outlining a plan for the international control of nuclear power.
The city of Salvador da Bahia, the first capital of Brazil, is founded.
Ludwig van Beethoven (24) has his debut performance as pianist in Vienna
Edmund Barton is elected Prime Minister in Australia's first parliamentary election
Capt Robert Scott, storm-bound in a tent near South Pole, makes last entry in his diary "the end cannot be far"
After a 4½ year trial Nelson Mandela is acquitted of treason in Pretoria
Chinese farmers discover the Terracotta Army near Xi'an, 8,000 clay warrior statues buried to guard tomb of China's 1st emperor Qin Shi Huang
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes at 10006.78 - above the 10,000 mark for the first time ever.
Russia signs the Treaty of Paris, ending the Crimean War
US buys Alaska from Russia for $7,200,000 (2 cents an acre - Seward's Folly)
15th Amendment to the US constitution is adopted, guarantees right to vote regardless of race
Dalai Lama flees China and is granted political asylum in India
Northern Ireland's Government and Parliament dissolved by the British Government and 'direct rule' from Westminster is introduced
Bernard of Clairvaux preaches his famous sermon in a field at Vézelay, urging the necessity of a Second Crusade. Louis VII is present, and joins the Crusade.
Queen Isabella and King Ferdinand of Aragon issue the Alhambra Decree which expels Jews from their Kingdoms of Castile and Aragon
English Parliament makes the Humble Petition to Lord Protector Oliver Cromwell offering him the crown: he declines
British parliament accepts Irish Home Rule law
US orders first combat troops to Vietnam
Byzantine Emperor Justin I names his nephew Justinian I as co-ruler and successor to the throne
Ruins of Pompeii rediscovered by Spaniard Rocque Joaquin de Alcubierre
Big Bang theory proposed in Physical Review by Alpher, Bethe & Gamow
Ayatollah Khomeini calls for an Islamic Republic in Iran
Steve Wozniak and Steve Jobs found Apple Computer in the garage of Jobs' parents house in Cupertino, California
Netherlands becomes the first country in the world to make same-sex marriage legal
Mehmed II begins his siege of Constantinople (İstanbul), which falls May 29
The Coinage Act is passed establishing the United States Mint and authorizing the $10 Eagle, $5 half-Eagle & 2.50 quarter-Eagle gold coins & silver dollar, ½ dollar, quarter, dime & half-dime
Napoleonic Wars: naval Battle of Copenhagen - The British led by Horatio Nelson destroy the Danish fleet.
US President Woodrow Wilson asks Congress to declare war against Germany
Ras Tafari Makonnen becomes Emperor Haile Selassie of Abyssinia (Ethiopia)
Several thousand Argentine troops seize the Falkland (Malvinas) Islands from Great Britain
English Long Parliament passes the Self-Denying Ordinance, limiting regional armies, significant step toward New Model Army
Joseph Stalin appointed General Secretary of the Russian Communist Party by Vladimir Lenin
US President Harry Truman signs Marshall Plan ($5B aid to 16 European countries)
The first portable cell phone call is made in New York City, United States.

Panama Papers published - 11.5 million confidential documents from offshore law firm Mossack Fonseca expose widespread illegal activities including fraud, kleptocracy, tax evasion and the violation of international sanctions by the world's elite in the world's largest ever data leak
Francis Drake knighted by Queen Elizabeth I aboard Golden Hind at Deptford
Battle at Postage Farina, Tunis: English fleet beats Barbary pirates
North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) treaty signed in Washington DC
US civil rights activist Martin Luther King Jr. assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee
World Trade Center, then the world's tallest building, opens in New York (110 stories)
Microsoft is founded as a partnership between Bill Gates and Paul Allen to develop and sell BASIC interpreters for the Altair 8800
Alexander Nevsky of Novgorod defeats Teutonic Knights in the Battle of the Ice
In the Battle of Maipú, Chile's independence movement - led by Bernardo O'Higgins and José de San Martín - win a decisive victory over Spain, leaving 2,000 Spaniards and 1,000 Chilean patriots dead.
Birkenhead Park, the first civic public park, designed by Joseph Paxton, opens in Birkenhead, England
Chile declares war on Bolivia and Peru, starting the War of the Pacific.
Cape Colony, the 1st European settlement in South Africa, established by Dutch East India Company under Jan van Riebeeck
1st US Congress begins regular sessions, Federal Hall, NYC
George Eastman begins selling his Kodak flexible rolled film for the first time
1st modern Olympic games open in Athens Greece [3/25 OS] American, James Connolly, wins 1st Olympic gold medal in mod history

Rwandan Genocide begins with the assassination of Rwandan President Juvénal Habyarimana and Burundian President Cyprien Ntaryamira with their plane being shot down by surface-to-air missiles, abruptly ending peace negotiations. Those responsible have never been identified.
Scholars' estimate for Jesus' crucifixion by Roman troops in Jerusalem
First draft of Corpus Juris Civilis (a fundamental work in jurisprudence) issued by Eastern Roman Emperor Justinian I
Johann Sebastian Bach's "St John Passion" premieres in Leipzig
US President Dwight D. Eisenhower in news conference is first to voice fear of a "domino-effect" of communism in Indo-China
The Internet's symbolic birth date: publication of RFC 1
The World Trade Organisation rules in favor of the United States in its long-running trade dispute with the European Union over bananas
Ayutthaya kingdom falls to Burmese invaders
William Ewart Gladstone introduces the first Irish Home Rule Bill into the British House of Commons.
Battle of Atbara River, Anglo-Egyptian forces crush 6,000 Sudanese
Opening of China's 1st parliament takes place in Peking (now Beijing)
Darfur conflict: The Humanitarian Ceasefire Agreement is signed by the Sudanese government and two rebel groups

Edward V (aged 12) succeeds his father Edward IV as king of England. He is never crowned, and disappears presumed murdered, after incarceration in the Tower of London with his younger brother Richard (the "Princes in the Tower")
British mariner Robert Jenkins' ear cut off by Spanish Guarde Costa in the Caribbean, later catalyst for war between Britain & Spain
Confederate General Robert E Lee and 26,765 troops surrender at Appomattox Court House to US Lieutenant General Ulysses S Grant (US Civil War)
Hudson Bay Company cedes its territory to Canada
John Major elected Prime Minister of the United Kingdom after his Conservative Party wins the most votes in British electoral history
Baghdad falls to U.S. forces ending the invasion of Iraqi but resulting in widespread looting
Lama Deshin Shekpa visits the Ming Dynasty capital at Nanjing and is awarded the title Great Treasure Prince of Dharma
1st Jewish ghetto established: Venice compels Jews to live in a specific area
"Big Ben", a 13.76 tonne bell, is recast in the Tower of Westminster
RMS Titanic sets sail from Southampton for her maiden (and final) voyage
Allies liberate 1st Nazi concentration camp, Buchenwald (Czech)
US, USSR & 70 other nations agree to ban biological weapons
The Good Friday/Belfast Agreement for Northern Ireland is signed by the British and Irish governments
Battle of Ravenna: French forces under Gaston de Foix defeat Holy League in a major battle of the Italian Wars
Hostilities formally cease in the American Revolutionary War
Napoleon abdicates unconditionally; he is exiled to Elba
The Shogunate is abolished in Japan.
Chartered Air India plane the "Kashmir Princess" is bombed and crashes into the South China Sea in a failed assassination attempt on Zhou Enlai by a Kuomintang secret agent
US President Lyndon B. Johnson signs  Civil Rights Act
Tanzanian army captures Kampala, the capital of Uganda forcing Ugandan dictator Idi Amin to flee into exile in Libya
Barack Obama and Raul Castro meet in Panama, the 1st meeting of US and Cuban heads of state since the Cuban Revolution
4th Crusade occupies & plunders Constantinople
1st US colonists on Pacific coast arrive at Cape Disappointment (Washington)
Kuomintang leader Chiang Kai-shek begins counter revolution in Shanghai
Russian cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin becomes the first person to orbit Earth (Vostok 1)
US Olympic Committee endorses a boycott of the Moscow Olympic games
The Seventh Crusade is defeated in Egypt, Louis IX of France is captured.
Edict of Nantes grants political rights to French Huguenots
George Frideric Handel's oratorio "Messiah" performed for the 1st time at New Music Hall in Dublin
1st Pony Express reaches Sacramento, California
Abyssinian War ends as British and Indian troops capture Magdala and Ethiopian Emperor commits suicide
US President Abraham Lincoln is shot by John Wilkes Booth at Ford's Theater in Washington
1st public showing of Thomas Edison's kinetoscope (moving pictures)
Dr Harry Plotz discovers vaccine against typhoid (NYC)
RMS Titanic hits an iceberg at 11.40pm off Newfoundland
Black Sunday: Severe sandstorm ravages the US Midwest, creating the "Dust Bowl"
1st Space Shuttle, Columbia 1, returns to Earth
The Human Genome Project is completed with 99% of the human genome sequenced to an accuracy of 99.99%
Samuel Johnson's "A Dictionary of the English Language" published in London
1st telephone installed: Boston-Somerville in Massachusetts
First modern Olympic games close in Athens, Greece
RMS Titanic sinks at 2:27 AM off Newfoundland as the band plays on
Jackie Robinson becomes 1st African-American to play in US major league baseball (Dodgers)
Boston Marathon bombings: 3 people are killed and 183 injured after two explosions near the finish line
Queen Anne of England knights Isaac Newton at Trinity College, Cambridge
Jacobite Rising 1745: Battle of Culloden, the last battle on British soil: Royalist troops under the Duke of Cumberland defeat the Jacobite army.
US Post Office issues 1st books of postage stamps
Vladimir Lenin issues his radical "April Theses" calling for Soviets to take power during the Russian Revolution [OS Apr 4]
Organization for European Economic Cooperation (EEC) forms in Paris
Treaty of Accession is signed in Athens admitting 10 new member states to the European Union
Geoffrey Chaucer tells the "Canterbury Tales" for the first time at the court of English King Richard II
Christopher Columbus signs contract with Spain to find the "Indies"
Treaty of Shimonoseki is signed ending the First Sino-Japanese War (1894-95)
1,400 Cuban exiles land in Bay of Pigs in a doomed attempt to overthrow Fidel Castro
Canada adopts its constitution
Bolesław Chrobry is crowned in Gniezno, becoming the first King of Poland.
The cornerstone of the current St. Peter's Basilica in the Vatican, is laid.
Paul Revere and William Dawes ride from Charleston to Lexington warning the "regulars are coming!"
Fighting ceases in the American Revolution, eight years to the day since it began.
San Francisco earthquake and fire kills nearly 4,000 while destroying 75% of the city
Colonel Gamal Abdal Nasser seizes power & becomes Prime Minister of Egypt
British explorer Captain James Cook first sights Australia
American Revolution begins - Lexington Common, shot "heard round the world"
Joan of Arc receives beatification by the Roman Catholic Church
Oklahoma City bombing - a truck bomb at Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building kills 168 & injures 500
Fidel Castro resigns from the Communist Party of Cuba's central committee after 45 years of holding the title.
First pasteurization test completed by Frenchmen Louis Pasteur and Claude Bernard
Marie and Pierre Curie isolate the radioactive element radium chloride
Balfour Declaration recognized, makes Palestine a British Mandate
British politician Enoch Powell makes his controversial "Rivers of Blood" speech
'The Troubles', the Northern Ireland conflict between republican and loyalist paramilitaries, British security forces, and civil rights groups, claims its 1000th victim
Climax of Berber Spring in Algeria sees hundreds of Berber political activists arrested
Columbine High School massacre: Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold kill 13 people and injure 24 others before committing suicide at Columbine High School, Colorado
The Deepwater Horizon drilling rig explodes, killing 11 and causing the rig to sink, causing a massive oil discharge into the Gulf of Mexico and an environmental diaster
Battle at Panipat: Central Asian conqueror Babur defeats Sultan Ibrahim Lodi, establishing the Mughal Empire in India
Brazilian revolutionary Tiradentes, is hanged, drawn and quartered in Rio de Janeiro
Bahá'u'lláh, founder of the Bahá'í Faith, enters gardens of Rivden, near Baghdad. Makes the declaration of aha'u'llah during 12 days spent there
World War I: German fighter ace Baron Manfred von Richthofen "The Red Baron", shot down and killed over Vaux sur Somme in France, Canadian pilot Arthur Roy Brown credited with the kill
Thousands of Chinese crowd into Beijing's Tiananmen Square cheering students demanding greater political freedom
Pedro Alvarez Cabral discovers Brazil & claims it for Portugal
Highlanders (Yankees) 1st game in New York at Hilltop Park vs Washington Senators, lose 3-1 before 11,950
1st military use of poison gas (chlorine, by Germany) in WW I
Holocaust Memorial Museum dedicated in Washington D.C.
7,000 Tutsi's slaughtered by Hutu in the stadium at Kibuye, Rwanda
243 people are injured in pro-democracy protest in Nepal after Nepali security forces open fire on protesters against King Gyanendra.

Paris Agreement on climate change signed in New York binding 195 nations to an increase in the global average temperature to less than 2°C above pre-industrial levels and to pursue efforts to limit the increase to 1.5°C
King Brian Boru of Ireland defeats Viking forces at Battle of Clontarf, freeing Ireland from foreign control
William Shakespeare's "The Merry Wives of Windsor" is first performed, with Queen Elizabeth I of England in attendance
Robert E Lee named commander of Virginia Confederate forces (US Civil War)
1st decimal coins issued in Britain (5 & 10 new pence, replacing shilling and two-shilling pieces)
AIDS-virus identified as HTLV-III (acquired immune deficiency syndrome)
Russo-Turkish War, -78: Russia declares war on the Ottoman Empire.
Spanish-American War: Spain declares war after rejecting US ultimatum to withdraw from Cuba
Easter Rising of Irish republicans against British occupation begins in Dublin

Vietnam War: American General William Westmoreland says in a news conference that the enemy had "gained support in the United States that gives him hope that he can win politically that which he cannot win militarily."
English Convention Parliament meets and votes to restore Charles II
Guillotine first used in France, executes highwayman Nicolas Pelletier
Thornton Affair: Open conflict begins over the disputed border of Texas, triggering the Mexican-American War.
"Elbe Day" - US and Soviet forces meet at Torgau, Germany on the Elbe River during the invasion of Germany in WWII
Francis Crick and James Watson's discovery of the double helix structure of DNA is published in "Nature" magazine
Bell labs announces the 1st solar battery made from silicon. It has about 6% efficiency.
Pazzi conspirators attack Lorenzo de'Medici & kill Giuliano de'Medici
1st English colony in American lands at Cape Henry, Virginia
Harlow Shapley and Heber D. Curtis hold "great debate" on the nature of nebulae, galaxies and size of the universe at US National Academy of Sciences, Washington, D.C.
Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, leader of France's Vichy collaborationist regime during WW II, arrested for treason
First modern container ship, the Ideal X, leaves Port Newark, New Jersey for Houston, Texas
Under international pressure, Syria withdraws the last of its 14,000 troop military garrison in Lebanon, ending its 29-year military domination of that country.
1st Spanish settlement in Philippines, Cebu City, forms

Steamboat "SS Sultana" explodes in the Mississippi River, killing up to 1,800 of the 2,427 passengers in the greatest maritime disaster in United States history. Most were paroled Union POWs on their way home.
The Australian Labor Party under Chris Watson becomes the first Labour government in the world
Italian partisans capture Benito Mussolini at Dongo (Lake Como)
The Superjumbo jet aircraft Airbus A380 makes its first flight from Toulouse, France

Establishment of the Pontifical and Royal University of Santo Tomas, The Catholic University of the Philippines, the oldest existing university in Asia and the largest Catholic university in the world.
British Captain James Cook, aboard the Endeavour, lands at Botany Bay in Australia
Fletcher Christian leads a mutiny on HMS Bounty against its captain William Bligh
First night air flight by Claude Grahame-White in England
1st commercial flight across Pacific operated by Pan Am
Andreas Baader and members of terrorist group the Red Army Faction (Baader-Meinhof Gang) jailed for life after a trial lasting nearly 2 years in Stuttgart, Germany
New Orleans falls to Union forces during US Civil War
Battle of Gate Pa (Pukehinahina): 1,700 British troops suffer their worst defeat of the New Zealand Wars at the hands of 230 entrenched Maori warriors in Tauranga
Irish republicans abandon the post office in Dublin and surrender unconditionally, marking the end of the Easter Rising
US Army liberates 31,601 in Nazi concentration camp in Dachau, Germany
Vietnam War: US begins to evacuate its citizens from Saigon in Operation Frequent Wind in response to advancing North Vietnamese forces, bringing an end to US involvement in the war
Wrecking cranes began tearing down the Berlin Wall at the Brandenburg Gate
The Chemical Weapons Convention of 1993 comes into force, outlaws production, stockpiling and use of chemical weapons among its signatories.
Roman Emperor Galerius issues Edict of Toleration, ending persercution of Christians in the Roman Empire
Islamic conquest of Iberia: Moorish troops led by Tariq ibn-Ziyad land at Gibraltar to begin their invasion of the Iberian Peninsula (Al-Andalus).
1st French colonists in North America: Jean Ribault & colonists arrive in Florida
George Washington is inaugurated as the first President of the United States of America
Charles Dickens' "A Tale Of Two Cities" is first published in literary periodical "All the Year Round" (weekly installments until Nov 26)
Chrysler automobile company files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy.
Acts of Union comes into force, uniting England and Scotland to form the United Kingdom of Great Britain
Publication of Species Plantarum by Linnaeus, and the formal start date of plant taxonomy adopted by the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature.
First emigrant wagon train leaves Independence, Missouri, for California
US general strike for 8-hour working day begins
US Admiral George Dewey commands "You may fire when you are ready, Gridley" as US route Spanish fleet at Manila
Empire State Building opens in New York City
World War II: Battle of Berlin ends as Soviet army takes Berlin and General Weidling surrenders
Arthur Miller wins Pulitzer Prize for "Death of a Salesman"
Falklands War: Argentine cruiser General Belgrano sunk by British submarine Conqueror, killing more than 350 men
Cyclone Nargis makes landfall in Myanmar killing over 130,000 people and leaving millions of people homeless
Osama bin Laden, the suspected mastermind behind the September 11 attacks and the FBI's most wanted man is killed by US special forces in Abbottabad, Pakistan
The Constitution of May 3 (the first modern constitution in Europe) is proclaimed by the Sejm of Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth.
Most of San Francisco destroyed by fire; 30 die
British General Strike: Trade Union Congress calls for a general strike 1 minute to midnight to support striking coal miners
Margaret Mitchell wins Pulitzer Prize for "Gone With the Wind"
World War II: German ship "Cap Arcona" laden with prisoners sunk by Royal Air Force in East Sea, 5,800 killed - one of largest maritime losses of life
Japan's post-war constitution goes into effect, granting universal suffrage, stripping Emperor Hirohito of all but symbolic power and outlawing Japan's right to make war

Battle of Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, the final battle between the Houses of Lancaster and York: the Prince of Wales, Edward of Westminster, killed and King Edward IV restored to his throne, restoring political stability to England until his death in 1483.
King Ferdinand VII of Spain signs the Decree of the 4th of May, returning Spain to absolutism.
Construction begins by the United States on the Panama Canal.
First Grammy Awards: Perry Como & Ella Fitzgerald win
Margaret Thatcher becomes the first woman to be elected Prime Minister of the United Kingdom
Kublai Khan, grandson of Genghis Khan, becomes ruler of the Mongol Empire.
Music Hall (Carnegie Hall) opens in New York, Tchaikovsky is guest conductor
Ethiopian Emperor Haile Selassie returns to Addis Ababa
West Germany is granted full sovereignty by its three occupying powers
First large-scale US Army ground units arrive in South Vietnam
Siege at Iranian Embassy in London ends as the SAS and police storm the building
Dutch colonist Peter Minuit buys Manhattan Island from local Indians for 60 guilders worth of trinkets
World's first postage stamp, the Penny Black, is issued in Great Britain
Exposition Universelle (World's Fair) in Paris opens with the recently completed Eiffel Tower serving as the entrance arch
Joseph Stalin becomes Premier of the Soviet Union
Roger Bannister of the UK becomes the 1st person to run a 4 minute mile, recording 3:59:4 at Iffley Road, Oxford
English siege of Orleans broken by Joan of Arc and the French army
Columbia University approves plans for awarding the Pulitzer Prize in several categories, after established by Joseph Pulitzer
RMS Lusitania sunk by German submarine off the southern coast of Ireland; 1198 lives lost
Germany and Italy announce an alliance known as the Rome-Berlin Axis
World War II: Unconditional German surrender to the Allies signed by General Alfred Jodl at Rheims
The concept of the integrated circuit, the basis for all modern computers, is first published by Geoffrey Dummer
English parliament declares Charles Stuart to be King Charles II of England
1st installment of Hans Christian Andersen "Fairy Tales" published by C. A. Reitzel in Copenhagen, Denmark
China cedes Taiwan to Japan under Treaty of Shimonoseki
V-E Day; WWII ends in Europe after Germany signs an unconditional surrender
World Health Organization announced smallpox had been eradicated
A new Northern Ireland Executive is formed with Ian Paisley (Democratic Unionist Party) as First Minister and Martin McGuinness (Sinn Féin) as Deputy First Minister
Treaty of Windsor between Portugal and England (the oldest diplomatic alliance in the world which is still in force)
British intelligence at Bletchley Park breaks German spy codes after capturing Enigma machines aboard the weather ship Muenchen
World War II: The Soviet Union marks Victory Day
US becomes the first country to legalize the birth control pill
The Beatles sign their 1st contract with EMI Parlophone
Second Continental Congress convenes in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania and issues paper currency for 1st time
First Barbary War: The Barbary pirates of Tripoli declare war on the United States of America (1st US foreign war)
Indian Mutiny against rule by the British East India Company begins with the revolt of the Sepoy soldiers in Meerut
Winston Churchill succeeds Neville Chamberlain as British Prime Minister
US atomic submarine USS Triton completes 1st submerged circumnavigation of the globe
Nelson Mandela sworn in as South Africa's 1st black president
Holy Roman Emperor Frederick I Barbarossa and 100,000 crusaders depart Regensburg for the Third Crusade
Pennsylvania Hospital founded by Dr. Thomas Bond and Benjamin Franklin
Daimler-Motoren-Gesellschaft and Benz & Cie begin their first joint venture (later merge into Mercedes-Benz)
In New York City, more than 170 countries decide to extend the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty indefinitely and without conditions.
India's poulation officially reaches 1 billion - Astha Arora named India's billionth baby
William Wilberforce makes his first major speech on abolition in the UK House of Commons, reasoning the slave trade morally reprehensible and an issue of natural justice
1st recorded shutout in pro baseball, Chicago 1, St Louis 0
Nazi blitzkrieg conquest of France began by crossing Muese River
Axis forces in North Africa surrender

Former US President Jimmy Carter arrives in Cuba for a five-day visit with Fidel Castro becoming first President of the United States, in or out of office, to visit the island since Castro's 1959 revolution.
Wenchuan earthquake, measuring 7.8 in magnitude occurs in Sichuan, China, killing over 87,000, injuring 374,643 and leaving homeless between 4.8 million and 11 million people
Arthur Phillip sets sails with 11 ships of criminals to Botany Bay, Australia
Republic of Ecuador is founded, with Juan Jose Flores as president
Great dustbowl storm sweeps across US prairies
Winston Churchill says I have nothing to offer but blood, toil, tears & sweat
Pope John Paul II is shot and critically wounded by Turkish gunman Mehemet Ali Agca in St Peter's Square, Vatican City
Approx 2,000 students begin hunger strike in Tiananmen Square, China
1st permanent English settlement in New World, Jamestown, Va
Delegates gather in Philadelphia to draw up US constitution
English country doctor Edward Jenner administers the first inoculation against smallpox, using cowpox pus, in Berkeley, Gloucestershire
Israel declares independence from under British administration
Last episode of Seinfeld on NBC (commercials are $2M for 30 seconds)
Pope Innocent IV issues the papal bull ad exstirpanda, which authorizes, but also limits, the torture of heretics in the Medieval Inquisition.
Johannes Kepler discovers harmonics law
Robert Walpole becomes effectively Britain's 1st prime minister (was: chief min)
National Woman Suffrage Association forms in New York, founded by Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton
McDonald's opens its first restaurant in San Bernardino, California.
AT&T becomes the 1st US corporation to have a million stockholders after young car salesman Brady Denton purchases 7 shares worth $1,078
USSR begins withdrawing its 115,000 troops from Afghanistan
Joan of Arc (Jeanne D'arc) canonized a saint
1st Academy Awards: "Wings", Emil Jannings & Janet Gaynor win
Operation Chastise: No. 617 Squadron RAF begins the famous Dambusters Raid, bombing the Möhne and Eder dams in the Ruhr valley with bouncing bombs
1st of 180,000+ Hungarian Jews reach Auschwitz
Human stem cells are successfully cloned
Pánfilo de Narváez departs Spain to explore Florida with 600 men - by 1536 only 4 survive
John Hawkins & Richard French patent the Reaping Machine
Fidel Castro offers to exchange Bay of Pigs prisoners for 500 bulldozers
Senate Watergate Committee begins its hearings
Massachusetts becomes the first U.S. state to legalize same-sex marriage
The center-right Hindu Nationalist Party, the BJP, wins landslide election victory in India
Mamluk Sultan Al-Ashraf Khalil and his forces take the last Christian stronghold of Acre
Napoleon Bonaparte proclaimed Emperor of France by the French Senate
Khodynka Tragedy: A mass panic on Khodynka Field, Moscow, during the festivities of the coronation of Russian Tsar Nicholas II, results in the deaths of 1,389 people
India becomes the sixth nation to explode an atomic bomb
Sri Lankan Civil War: The LTTE are defeated by the Sri Lankan government, ending almost 26 years of fighting between the two sides.
Anne Boleyn, second wife of English King Henry VIII, is beheaded at the Tower of London on charges of adultery, incest and treason
Massachusetts Bay, Plymouth, Connecticut and New Harbor form the United Colonies of New England
England is declared a Commonwealth by an act of the Long Parliament making England a republic for the next 11 years
German Chancellor Otto von Bismarck takes possession of Cameroon and Togoland

US Congress passes the Private Mailing Card Act, allowing private publishers and printers to produce postcards though they had to be labelled "Private Mailing Cards" until 1901 and become known as "souvenir cards"
Mustafa Kemal Atatürk lands at Samsun on the Black Sea coast, beginning the Turkish War of Independence
Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama arrives at Calicut, India becoming the first European to reach India by sea
Shakespeare's Sonnets are first published in London, perhaps illicitly, by the publisher Thomas Thorpe.
US Homestead Act becomes law which provides cheap land for the settlement of the American West
History of cinema: The first public display of Thomas Edison's prototype kinetoscope to members of the National Federation of Women's Club
At 7:40 AM, Charles Lindbergh takes off from New York to cross the Atlantic for Paris, aboard Spirit of St Louis (1st non-stop flight)
Saudi Arabia becomes independent of Great Britain (Treaty of Jeddah)
Hubble Space Telescope sends its 1st photographs from space
Mount Unzen on Japan's Shimabara Peninsula, erupts creating a tsunami, killing about 15,000; Japan's deadliest volcanic eruption
1st Democratic National Convention (Baltimore)
-July 28] French regular troops attack Commune of Paris; 17,000 die
Federation Internationale de Football Association (FIFA) forms in Paris
Aviator Charles Lindbergh, in the Spirit of St Louis, lands in Paris after the first solo air crossing of Atlantic
1st transatlantic solo flight by a woman (Amelia Earhart) lands in Ireland
Stanislav Petrov awarded World Citizen Award for averting a potential nuclear war in 1983 after correctly guessing Russian early warning system at fault
1st atlas 'Theatrum Orbis Terrarum' (Theatre of the World), published by Abraham Ortelius in Antwerp with 70 maps
1st wagon train with 700 - 1000 migrants, departs Independence, Missouri for Oregon
Adolf Hitler & Benito Mussolini sign "Pact of Steel"
First US rocket (WAC Corporal) to reach edge of space fired from White Sands Missile Range New Mexico

Royal Thai Armed Forces, led by General Prayut Chan-o-cha stage a coup in Thailand, suspending the kingdom's constitution and taking control of the government, the 12th since the country's first coup in 1932

Second Defenestration of Prague: Two Catholic Lords Regent and their secretary are thrown out of a window and amazingly are not seriously injured by the 70 foot (21m) fall. Triggers the Thirty Years' War.
Benjamin Franklin announces his invention of bifocals
South American independence leader Simón Bolívar enters Mérida, leading the invasion of Venezuela, and is proclaimed El Libertador ("The Liberator")
Federal Republic of [West] Germany created out of the American, British and French occupation zones
Mao Zedong starts the "Great Leap Forward" movement in China
The Good Friday Agreement is accepted in a referendum in Northern Ireland with 75% voting yes.
Nomenclator of Leiden University Library appears, the first printed catalog of an institutional library.
John Wesley is converted, launching the Methodist movement; the day is celebrated annually by Methodists as Aldersgate Day.
Samuel Morse taps out "What hath God wrought" in the world's first telegraph message
German battleship Bismarck sinks the British battle cruiser HMS Hood; 1,416 die, 3 survive
Section 28 is passed as law by Parliament in the United Kingdom which prohibited the promotion of homosexuality. Repealed 2001/2004
The Ship "Le Grand St Antoine" reaches Marseille, bringing Europe's last major plague outbreak. Kills around 100,000.
In the May Revolution, citizens of Buenos Aires expel the Spanish Viceroy Cisneros during Semana de Mayo
British House of Commons passes the Irish Home Rule Bill
Track and field athlete Jesse Owens equals or breaks 4 world records in 45 minutes at a Big Ten meet at Ferry Field in Ann Arbor, Michigan. Remembered as "the greatest 45 minutes ever in sport".
Hands Across America - 6.5 million people hold hands from California to NY
England, France & Netherlands sign Drievoudig Covenant against Spain
Dow Jones begins an index of 12 industrial stocks (closing is 40.94)
At Masjed Soleyman (مسجد سليمان) in southwest Persia, the first major commercial oil strike in the Middle East is made, rights acquired by the United Kingdom
Henry Ford and the Ford Motor Company produce the last (and 15th million) Model T Ford / Tin Lizzie
South Africa elects a nationalist government under D. F. Malan with an apartheid policy
EMI releases "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band" a few days early in the UK; it would go to number one for 15 weeks in the US and 22 weeks in the UK
The United States Army veteran Terry Nichols is found guilty of 161 state murder charges for helping carry out the Oklahoma City bombing.
Habeaus Corpus Act (strengthening person's right to challenge unlawful arrest & imprisonment) passes in England
Saint Petersburg (Leningrad) founded by Russian Tsar Peter the Great
British and Allied forces begin the evacuation of Dunkirk (Operation Dynamo) during WWII
The International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia indicts Slobodan Milošević and four others for war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in Kosovo
Earthquake strikes Java, Indonesia at 5:53:58 AM local time (22:53:58 UTC May 26) devastating Bantul and the city of Yogyakarta, killing over 6,600 people
Joan of Arc is accused of relapsing into heresy by donning male clothing again, providing justification for her execution
Spanish Armada under the Duke of Medina-Sidonia departs Lisbon to invade England
US Congress authorizes native Indian to be removed from all states to the western prairie
Alan Turing submits "On Computable Numbers" for publication, in which he set out the theoretical basis for modern computers.
White House "plumbers" break into the Democratic National Headquarters at Watergate in Washington D.C.
