Constantinople, capital of the Eastern Roman Empire falls to the Turks under Muhammad II; ends the Byzantine Empire
Battle of Sacheon: Korean navy led by Admiral Yi Sun Shin repels a Japanese fleet - first use of Korean Turtle ship
On his 30th birthday Charles II returns to London from exile in the Netherlands to claim the English throne after the Puritan Commonwealth comes to an end
Sojourner Truth addresses 1st Black Women's Rights Convention, which was held in Akron, Ohio
Edmund Hillary (NZ) and Tenzing Norgay (Nepal) are first to reach the summit of Mount Everest as part of a British Expedition
Hundred Years' War: 19 year old Joan of Arc is burned at the stake by an English-dominated tribunal in Rouen, France
Spanish explorer Hernando de Soto discovers Florida
Mexico ratifies treaty giving US; New Mexico, California & parts of Nevada, Utah, Arizona & Colorado in return for $15 million
"Decoration Day", later called Memorial Day is first observed in Northern US states
1st car accident occurs, Henry Wells hits a cyclist in NYC
Treaty of London signed by the Great Powers, the Ottoman Empire and the victorious Balkan League (Serbia, Greece, Kingdom of Bulgaria, and Montenegro) bringing an end to the First Balkan War
Martin Frobisher sails from Harwich, England, to Frobisher Bay, Canada. Eventually mines fools gold, famously used to pave the streets of London.
Union of South Africa declares its independence from the United Kingdom

Battle of Jutland: Largest naval battle of World War I between the British Grand Fleet and the German High Seas Fleet which killed 8,645 in an inconclusive battle but strategic British victory. The German fleet never put to sea again.
7.7 magnitude earthquake hits Quetta in Balochistan, British Raj (Pakistan) killing an estimated 50,000 people
Communists seize power in Hungary
Usain Bolt breaks the world record in the 100m sprint, with a wind-legal (+1.7m/s) 9.72 seconds
Beijing, under control of Jurchen ruler Emperor Xuanzong of Jin, is captured by the Mongols under Genghis Khan, ending the Battle of Beijing
Battle of Öland: allied Danish-Dutch forces defeat the Swedish navy in the Baltic Sea, during the Scanian War (1675–79)
Kenya becomes a republic with Jomo Kenyatta as its 1st President
1st transmission of CNN, the Cable News Network
European Central Bank is founded in Brussels to define and execute the European Union's monetary policy
King Gaiseric & the Vandals sack Rome - Rome looted for 14 days
Robert E Lee takes command of Confederate armies of North Virgina during US Civil War
Guglielmo Marconi applies to patent the radio, accepted 2 July 1897
Babe Ruth, 40, announces his retirement as a player
Coronation of Queen Elizabeth II in Westminster Abbey
10,000 Chinese soldiers are blocked by 100,000 citizens protecting students demonstrating for democracy in Tiananmen Square, Beijing
Dutch West India Company (WIC) receives charter for The West Indies (The Americas, Caribbean and West Africa)
Chile and Peru sign the Treaty of Lima, finally resolving their border dispute from the War of the Pacific (1879–83). Chile keeps Arica and Peru regains Tacna.
A mob of 60 from the Los Angeles Naval Reserve Armory beat up everyone perceived to be Hispanic, starting the week-long Zoot Suit Riots.
Ixtoc I rig in the Gulf of Mexico blows, spilling 3 million barrels of oil in one of the worst oil spills in history
Beginning of the Tiananmen Square Massacre as Chinese troops open fire on pro-democracy supporters in Beijing
Great Upheaval: New England planters arrive to claim land in Nova Scotia, Canada taken from the Acadians

British complete the "Miracle of Dunkirk" by evacuating 338,226 allied troops from France via a flotilla of over 800 vessels including Royal Navy destroyers, merchant marine boats, fishing boats, pleasure craft and even lifeboats
US, Soviet Union, Britain and France agree to divide up occupied Germany
Eastern Europe's 1st partial free elections in 40 years held in Poland, Solidarity Party comes to power
Tiananmen Square Massacre: Chinese troops clear the square of student protesters, unofficial figures place death toll near 1,000.
Sultan Bargash bin Said under British pressure closes the infamous slave market of Zanzibar in modern day Tanzania
US Secretary of State George Marshall outlines the "Marshall Plan" to rebuild Western Europe
State of siege proclaimed in Iran, Ayatollah Khomeini arrested
Six-day war begins between Israel and the neighboring Arab states of Egypt, Jordan and Syria
AIDS Epidemic officially begins when US Centers for Disease Control reports on pneumonia affecting five homosexual men in Los Angeles
World's first today in history program with editable data "TODAY", invented by Michael Butler runs for the first time on a mainframe computer
Indira Gandhi orders an attack on Sikh's holiest site, the Golden Temple
Gustav Vasa is elected King of Sweden, marking the end of the Kalmar Union.
1st slaves arrive in Louisiana
Operation Neptune, D-Day: 150,000 strong Allied Expeditionary Force lands in Normandy, France in WWII
30,000 Israeli troops invade Lebanon to drive out the PLO

A near-Earth asteroid estimated at 10 metres diameter explodes over the Mediterranean Sea between Greece and Libya. Resulting explosion estimated to have a force of 26 kilotons, more powerful than the Nagasaki atomic bomb.
Treaty of Tordesillas: Spain and Portugal divide the new world along a meridian 370 leagues west of the Cape Verde islands, off the west coast of Africa
English King Charles I ratifies the Petition of Rights
Louis XIV crowned King of France
Vatican City becomes a sovereign state
The Supreme Court of the United States decides on Griswold v. Connecticut, effectively legalizing the use of contraception by married couples.
Sony introduces the Betamax videocassette recorder for sale to the public
Vikings in long ships from modern-day Norway plunder St Cuthbert's monastery on Lindisfarne Island, off the northeast coast of England
King Richard I of England arrives at Acre in modern day Israel to join the Siege of Acre during the Third Crusade
James Madison introduces a proposed Bill of Rights in the US House of Representatives
Nova Aquila, brightest nova since Kepler's nova of 1604, discovered
New Zealand's Labour government legislates against nuclear weapons and nuclear powered vessels in NZ. Only nation to legislate against nuclear power.
Roman Emperor Nero commits suicide, imploring his secretary Epaphroditos to slit his throat to evade a Senate-imposed death by flogging.
Odo of Aquitaine defeats the Moors in the Battle of Toulouse.
Book of Common Prayer is adopted by the Church of England
End of the Congress of Vienna: New European political situation is set.
Silver jubilee of Queen Elizabeth II of Great Britain celebrated with fireworks
British lease on the New Territories in Hong Kong expires
Third Crusade: Holy Roman Emperor Frederick I Barbarossa drowns while crossing the Saleph River (modern Turkey) leading an army to Jerusalem
A landslide dam on the Dadu River caused by earthquake ten days earlier collapses, killing 100,000 in the Sichuan province of China
US Marines land in Cuba during Spanish-American War
Great Arab Revolt begins against ruling Ottoman turks
US Equal Pay Act signed into law by President John F. Kennedy
Apple Computer ships its first Apple II computers

Emperor Taizong of Tang of China, sends envoys to the Xueyantuo bearing gold and silk for the release of Chinese prisoners captured during transition from Sui to Tang from northern frontier; succeeds in freeing 80,000
Continental Congress creates committee (Thomas Jefferson, John Adams, Benjamin Franklin, Roger Sherman, and Robert R. Livingston) to draft a Declaration of Independence
US President JFK says segregation is morally wrong & that it is "time to act"
Margaret Thatcher is 1st British Prime Minister in 160 years to win a third consecutive term
Islamic State of Iraq forces seize control of government offices and other important buildings in the northern city of Mosul
Peasants' Revolt: in England, rebels arrive at Blackheath.
Beginning of the French colonization of Algeria: 34,000 French soldiers land 27 kilometers west of Algiers, at Sidi Ferruch
Al Capone is indicted on 5,000 counts of prohibition & perjury
Anne Frank gets her diary as a birthday present in Amsterdam
Nelson Mandela is sentenced to life in prison in South Africa
Anglo-Portuguese Treaty of Alliance (world's oldest extant) signed in London
US House of representatives passes 14th Amendment (Civil rights)
Congress of Berlin begins, determines the territories of the states in the Balkan peninsula following the Russo-Turkish War of 1877–78
The last British troops leave the Suez Canal Zone in Egypt
President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea meets Kim Jong-il, leader of North Korea, for the beginning of the first ever inter-Korea summit, in the northern capital of Pyongyang.
Richard II in England meets leaders of Peasants' Revolt on Blackheath. The Tower of London is stormed by rebels who enter without resistance
Battle of Naseby, Leicestershire: "New Model Army" under Oliver Cromwell & Thomas Fairfax beat royalists forces of English King Charles I
Badi VII, king of Sennar, surrenders his throne and realm to Ismail Pasha, general of the Ottoman Empire, bringing the 300 year old Sudanese kingdom to an end
Auschwitz concentration camp opens in Nazi controlled Poland with Polish POWs (approx. 3 million would die within its walls)
Estonia loses 11,000 inhabitants as a consequence of mass deportations into Siberia
Argentina surrenders to Britain, ending the 74-day Falklands Islands conflict
King John signs Magna Carta at Runnymede, near Windsor, England
George Washington appointed commander-in-chief of the Continental Army, the day after Congress establishes the force
Tsunami strikes Shinto festival on beach at Sanriku, Japan; 27,000 are killed, 9,000 injured and 13,000 houses destroyed
World War II: France surrenders to NAZI Germany, German troops occupy Paris
Real estate mogul Donald Trump launches his campaign for US President
Abraham Lincoln says "A house divided against itself cannot stand" accepting Illinois Republican Party's nomination for the Senate
Salvation Army forms in London
Bloomsday (date of events in James Joyce's Ulysses)
US Congress accepts FDR's "New Deal"

Israel complies with UN Security Council Resolution 425 after 22 years, which calls on Israel to completely withdraw from Lebanon. Israel withdraws from all of Lebanon, except the disputed Sheba Farms.
Ali ibn Abu Talib chosen kalief of Islam
After 200 years of crusader control, Acre is the last crusader stronghold reconquered and destroyed by the Mamluks under Sultan al-Ashraf Khalil
Sir Francis Drake lands on coast of California at Drakes Bay, names it "New Albion"
Mumtaz Mahal dies during childbirth. Her husband, Mughal emperor Shah Jahan I, then spends more than 20 years building her tomb, the Taj Mahal
Republican Party opens its 1st national convention in Philadelphia
Coronation of the Chinese governor Li Yuan as Emperor Gaozu of Tang, the new Emperor of China, initiating three centuries of the Tang Dynasty's rule over China
War of  begins as US declares war against Britain
Battle of Waterloo; Napoleon and France defeated by British forces under Wellington and Prussian troops under Blucher
American aviator Amelia Earhart becomes the 1st woman to fly across the Atlantic Ocean landing at Burry Port, Wales
Winston Churchill's "this was their finest hour" speech urging perseverance during Battle of Britain delivered to British House of Commons
UN Commission on Human Rights adopts the International Declaration of Human Rights
Sir Robert Peel introduces the Metropolitan Police Act  into Parliament to establish a unified police force for London
Slavery outlawed in US territories
World War II: First day of the 2 day Battle of the Philippine Sea, US naval forces defeat Japanese fleet
Colombian drug lord Pablo Escobar surrenders to police
Tiger Woods wins golf's US Open by 15 shots, a record for all majors, with a US Open to-par record score of -12
Battle of the Catalaunian Plains: Roman and Visigoths forces defeat Attila the Hun in north east France
The University of Oxford receives its charter
Tennis Court Oath (for a new constitution) in France made at Versailles
Samuel Morse patents his telegraph
1st female PhD from an American University, earned by Caroline Willard Baldwin (in Science) at Cornell University
US Constitution comes into effect when New Hampshire is the 9th state to ratify it
First Victoria Cross won during bombardment of Bomarsund in the Aland Islands (Crimean War)
Lord Mountbatten resigns as Governor General of India (formerly the last Viceroy)
7.7 Manjil-Rudbar Earthquake with hundreds of aftershocks hits Iran; killing about 50,000
English mathematician Andrew Wiles proves last theorem of Fermat
Galileo Galilei forced to recant his Copernican views that the Earth orbits the Sun by the Pope (Vatican only admits it was wrong on Oct 31, 1992!)
Royal Greenwich Observatory established in England by Charles II
Somerset v Stewart court case finds slavery unsupported by English common law, encouraging the abolitionist movement
Beginning of the June Days uprising in Paris by French workers
John Dillinger is informally named America's first Public Enemy Number One
Germany, Italy and Romania declare war on the Soviet Union
World's oldest parliament, the Icelandic Parliament, the Alþingi (anglicised as Althing or Althingi), established
Christopher Latham Sholes patents the "Type-writer"
The International Olympic Committee is founded at the Sorbonne, Paris, at the initiative of Baron Pierre de Coubertin
1st contraceptive pill is made available for purchase in the U.S.
Hurricane Agnes becomes America's costliest natural disaster, effecting 15 states, with 119 deaths and $3 billion in damage
1st extraterrestrial message sent from Earth into space
United Kingdom votes to leave the European Union in their "Brexit" referundum
John Cabot claims Eastern Canada for England (believes he has found Asia in Nova Scotia)
Henry VIII is crowned King of England in Westminster Abbey
1st republican constitution in France adopted
Napoleon Bonaparte's forces invade Russia crossing the Neman River
US President Franklin Pierce signs the Gadsden Purchase, buying 29,670 square-miles (76,800 square km) from Mexico for $10 million (now southern Arizona and New Mexico)
1st exhibition by Pablo Picasso, 19, opens in Paris
1st radar detection of planes, Anacostia, Washington, D.C.
French physician Jean-Baptiste Denys performs the 1st human blood transfusion
Venetian Elena Cornaro Piscopia is awarded a doctorate of philosophy, the 1st woman to receive a university doctoral degree or PhD

Battle of the Little Bighorn: US 7th Cavalry under Brevet Major General George Armstrong Custer wiped out by Sioux and Cheyenne warriors led by Chiefs Crazy Horse and Sitting Bull in what has become famously known as "Custer's Last Stand"
US President Herbert Hoover authorizes building of Boulder Dam (Hoover Dam)
North Korea invades South Korea, beginning the Korean War
Roman Emperor Julian is killed during retreat from the Sassanid Empire. General Jovian is proclaimed Emperor by troops on the battlefield.

Battle of Fleurus: major victory by forces of the First French Republic under General Jean-Baptiste Jourdan over the Coalition Army (Great Britain, Hanover, Dutch Republic, and Habsburgs) first use of reconnaissance balloon
The first 62 recipients are awarded the Victoria Cross for valour in the Crimean war by Queen Victoria
1st US Expeditionary Force arrives in France during World War I
Panama Canal's third set of locks opens for commercial traffic, doubling the Canal’s capacity at an estimated cost of $5.25 billion
Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo sets sail from the Mexican port of Navidad to explore the west coast of North America on behalf of the Spanish Empire
War of the Austrian Succession: Battle of Dettingen: in Bavaria, King George II of Britain personally leads troops into battle. The last time a British monarch would command troops in the field.
1st color TV demo, performed by Bell Laboratories in NYC
North Korean troops reach Seoul, UN asks members to aid South Korea, Harry Truman orders US Air Force & Navy into Korean conflict
The world's first ATM is installed in Enfield, London
Ottomans defeat Serbian army in the bloody Battle of Kosovo, opening the way for the Ottoman conquest of Southeastern Europe
King Carlos I elected Holy Roman Catholic Emperor Charles V
Coronation of Queen Victoria in Westminster Abbey, London
Franz Ferdinand, Archduke of Austria and his wife Sophie are assassinated in Sarajevo by young Serb nationalist Gavrilo Princip at 10.45, the casus belli of WWI
Treaty of Versailles, ending WWI and establishing the League of Nations, is signed in France
Shakespeare's Globe Theatre burns down
First (known) recording of classical music made, Handel's Israel in Egypt on wax cylinder
South Africa begins implementing apartheid; no mixed marriages
Civil Rights Act of  passed after 83-day filibuster in the US Senate
World's first female diocesan Anglican bishop, Dr Penny Jamieson, appointed in New Zealand
US reopens Guantanamo Naval Base to process refugees
The Spaniards are expelled from Tenochtitlan.
Famous debate on Charles Darwin's theory of evolution held at the Oxford University Museum and dominated by arguments between Thomas Henry Huxley and Bishop Samuel Wilberforce
In Russia, the "Potemkin" arrives at Odessa, where sailors take the bodies of dead crewman ashore; sailors join civilians in revolutionary actions of the ' Revolution'
Tunguska Event: a giant fireball most likely caused by the air burst of a large meteoroid or comet impacts in Siberia
"Night of Long Knives" - Hitler stages a bloody purge of the Nazi party
Superman 1st appears in DC Comics' Action Comics Series issue #1
South African ANC President Nelson Mandela meets with UN Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali at Dakar
Matsuo Basho, zen poet, leaves for 150 days journey on Honshu Japan
The joint reading of Charles Darwin and Alfred Russel Wallace's papers on evolution to the Linnean Society.
Battle of Gettysburg, Pa; Lee's northward advance halted
The Dominion of Canada is formed, comprising the provinces of New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Ontario & Quebec, with John A. Macdonald serving as the first Prime Minister
First day of the Battle of the Somme: the British Army suffers its worst day, losing 19,240 men (WWI)
The Communist Party of China is founded and Chen Duxiu elected its leader
United Kingdom returns Hong Kong and the New Territories to the People's Republic of China
Incident at Xuanwu Gate: in fear of assassination, Li Shimin ambushes and kills his rival brothers Li Yuanji and Li Jiancheng
Continental Congress resolves "these United Colonies are & of right ought to be Free & Independent States"
Bahia Independence Day: the end of Portuguese rule in Brazil, with the final defeat of the Portuguese crown loyalists in the province of Bahia
Hitler orders invasion of Britain (Operation Sealion)
US President Lyndon B. Johnson signs Civil Rights Act & Voting Rights Act into law
Panic in tunnel of Mecca: 1,426 pilgrims trampled to death
Battle of Adrianople: Roman Emperor Constantine I defeats his co-emperor Licinius, who flees to Byzantium
Battle of Horns of Hattin: Saladin, Sultan of Egypt and Syria, destroys Jerusalem's crusader army
Battle of Gettysburg, largest battle ever fought on the American continent, ends in a major victory for the Union during the US Civil War
Dow Jones publishes its 1st stock index, the Dow Jones Transportation Average

UK House of Commons announces that the Stone of Scone, aka the Stone of Destiny, used in the coronation of Scottish (and subsequently English and British monarchs), will be returned to Scotland after 700 years in Westminster Abbey
US Congress proclaims the Declaration of Independence and independence from Britain
James Hutton, geologist, publicly reads an abstract of his theory of uniformitarianism for the first time at the meeting of the Royal Society of Edinburgh
The Louisiana Purchase is announced to the American people
Huskar Colliery Mining Disaster in Silkstone England: mining pit floods drown 26 children, leads to 1842 'Mines and Collieries Act' bans women and children working underground
Hungarian physicist Leo Szilard patents the chain-reaction design for the atomic bomb.
Isaac Newton's great work PRINCIPIA published by Royal Society in England. Outlines his laws of motion and universal gravitation.
Venezuelan Declaration of Independence: 7 provinces declare themselves independent of Spain
Frederick Douglass, fugitive slave, delivers his 'What to the Slave Is the Fourth of July?' speech to the Ladies' Anti-Slavery Society in Rochester, condemns the celebration as hypocritical sham
US Secret Service begins operating under the Treasury Department
First Indonesian presidential election by the people - first round (eventually won by Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono)
Papal bull of Pope Clement VI issued during the Black Death stating Jews not to blame and urging their protection
US Congress unanimously resolves the name of US currency to the "dollar" and adopts decimal coinage
Louis Pasteur successfully tests an anti-rabies vaccine
Biafran War erupts as Nigerian forces invade starting Nigerian Civil war
California passes 1st "no fault" divorce law
Battle of Otumba Mexico: Hernán Cortés and the Tlaxcalans defeat a numerically superior Aztec force
British Museum founded by an Act of Parliament (opens in 1759)
Japanese & Chinese troops clash at the Marco Polo Bridge, beginning of Second Sino-Japanese War
Alleged and disputed Roswell UFO incident occured
Coordinated terrorist bomb blasts strike London's public transport system during the morning rush hour killing 52 and injuring 700
Influenced by Live 8, the G8 leaders pledge to double 2004 levels of aid to Africa from US$25 to US$50 billion by the year 2010.
First Crusade: 15,000 starving Christian soldiers march in religious procession around Jerusalem as its Muslim defenders look on
Portuguese navigator Vasco da Gama departs on his first voyage, becoming the 1st European to reach India by sea
Vermont introduces new constitution making it the 1st US state to abolish slavery
Dr Benjamin Waterhouse gives 1st cowpox vaccination in the US to his son to prevent smallpox
Commodore Matthew C. Perry sails his frigate Susquehanna into Tokyo Bay, opening Japan to Western influence and trade
500th anniversary of the Russian Orthodox Church celebrated in Moscow
Turko-Mongol ruler Tamerlane (Timur) destroys Baghdad, killing 20,000
Russo-Swedish War: Second Battle of Svensksund - in the Baltic Sea, the Swedish Navy captures one third of the Russian fleet.
Daniel Williams performs 1st successful open heart surgery without anesthesia
British battleship HMS Vanguard explodes at Scapa Flow (the result of an internal explosion of faulty cordite), killing 804
Henry Kissinger visits the People's Republic of China to negotiate a detente between the US and China
The African Union is established in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia. The first chairman is Thabo Mbeki, President of South Africa.
American Revolution: Louis XVI of France declares war on the Kingdom of Great Britain
Battle of Britain begins as Nazi forces attack shipping convoys in the English Channel

French foreign intelligence agents blow up the Greenpeace boat Rainbow Warrior in Auckland harbor, New Zealand to prevent it interfering with French nuclear tests in the South Pacific. Dutch photographer Fernando Pereira is killed.
Boris Yeltsin sworn in as 1st elected President of the Russian Federation
The American Episcopal Church becomes the first to approve a rite for blessing gay marriages
Chinese fleet commander Zheng He sets sail to explore the world for the first time
Pope Clement VII excommunicates England's King Henry VIII
Charlotte Cooper beats Hélène Prévost to become the 1st female Olympic tennis champion and the 1st individual female Olympic champion in any sport
Franklin Roosevelt announces that he will run for a fourth term as President of the United States
7,000 Bosnian Muslim men are massacred when Bosnian Serbs overrun the UN 'safe haven' of Srebrenica.
Britain's King Charles II ratifies Habeas Corpus Act allowing prisoners right to be imprisoned to be examined
Battle of Boyne: in Ireland, Protestant King William III defeats English Catholic King James II
150,000 Ulstermen gather and resolve to resist Irish Home Rule by force of arms; since the British Liberals have promised the Irish nationalists Home Rule, civil war appears imminent
World War II: Battle of Prokhorovka - Russians defeat German forces in one of the largest ever tank battles
US Surgeon General Leroy Burney connects smoking with lung cancer
Captain James Cook begins 2nd voyage aboard the Resolution to the South Seas to search for Terra Australis (Southern continent)
Source of Mississippi River discovered by American geographer Henry Schoolcraft
1st-ever football (soccer) World Cup competition begins in Uruguay
Greatest tank battle in history ends with Russia's defeat of Germany at Kursk, almost 6,000 tanks take part, 2,900 lost by Germany
"Live Aid" concerts held at both Wembley Stadium (London) and John F. Kennedy Stadium (Philadelphia) raises over $70 million for African famine relief
Bastille Day - the French Revolution begins with the fall of the Bastille Prison
US Sedition Act prohibits "false, scandalous & malicious" writing against government
NSDAP (Nazis) becomes only political party in Germany
6,000 Lithuanian Jews are exterminated at Viszalsyan Camp
386BSD is released by Lynne Jolitz and William Jolitz, starting the open source operating system revolution. Linus Torvalds release "Linux" soon afterwards.
City of Jerusalem is captured and plundered by Christian forces during the First Crusade
John Ball, a leader in the Peasants' Revolt, is hung, drawn and quartered in the presence of Richard II of England.

Battle of Grunwald (2nd Battle of Tannenburg), one of Medieval Europe's largest battles during Poland-Lithuanian Teutonic War. Polish King Władysław Jagiełło and Lithuanian Grand Duke Vytautas defeat Teutonic Ulrich von Jungingen
The Rosetta Stone is found in the Egyptian village of Rosetta by French Captain Pierre-François Bouchard during Napoleon's Egyptian Campaign
18 Nobel laureates sign the Mainau Declaration against nuclear weapons, later co-signed by 34 more laureates
Muslim Era begins - Muhammad begins flight from Mecca to Medina (Hijra)

Three Roman legates fracture relations between Western and Eastern Christian churches by placing invalid Papal Bull of Excommunication on altar of Hagia Sophia during liturgy. Often dated start of the East-West Schism.
Public debate between Martin Luther & theologist John Eck at Pleissenburg Castle in Liepzig, Luther denies the divine right of the Pope
La Paz, Bolivia declares its independence from the Spanish Crown and forms the Junta Tuitiva. The first independent government in Spanish America, led by Pedro Domingo Murillo
A Bolshevik firing squad at Ekaterinburg, Siberia, executes Tsar Nicholas II of Russia, his family and several retainers
6 inhabitants of Scillium in North Africa are executed for being Christians. Earliest record of Christianity in that part of the world.
Siege of Constantinople begins during the fourth Crusade, Crusaders aboad a Venetian fleet attack the city
Catherine II becomes tsarina of Russia following the murder of Peter III
Spanish generals Francisco Franco and Emilio Mola lead a right-wing uprising, starting the Spanish Civil War
Potsdam Conference (Truman, Stalin, Churchill) holds 1st meeting

Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 is shot down over Eastern Ukraine by a Buk surface-to-air missile launched from pro-Russian separatist-controlled territory, killing all 283 passengers and 15 crew on board
Great Fire of Rome begins under the Emperor Nero
Adolf Hitler publishes Mein Kampf (original title was the catchy "Four and a Half Years (of Struggle) Against Lies, Stupidity and Cowardice")
Spanish Civil War : General Francisco Franco issues manifesto and leds uprising with army in Morocco
Kim Jong-un is officially appointed Supreme Leader of North Korea and given the rank of Marshal in the Korean People's Army
Detroit, Michigan, files for bankruptcy, becoming the largest US municipal bankruptcy ever at $18.5 billion
Astronomer Johannes Kepler has an epiphany and develops his theory of the geometrical basis of the universe
Brunel's steamship the SS Great Britain is launched, becomes first ocean-going craft with an iron hull or screw propeller and the largest vessel afloat in the world
1st US women's rights convention held in Seneca Falls NY, organised by Elizabeth Cady Stanton & Lucretia Mott
Tennessee is 1st to ratify 14th Amendment to the US constitution, guaranteeing civil rights
Billboard publishes earliest known "Last Week's 10 Best Sellers among Popular Songs" Malinda's Wedding Day is #1
British PM Winston Churchill launched his "V for Victory" campaign
Sioux Indian Chief Sitting Bull, surrenders to US federal troops
Congresswoman Alice Mary Robertson becomes the first woman to preside over the US House of Representatives
Armistice for Indo-China signed, Vietnam separates into North & South
1st Moon Landing: Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin from Apollo 11, 530 million watch live global broadcast
US Viking 1 lands on Mars at Chryse Planitia, 1st Martian landing
Crete Earthquake followed by tsunami around the Eastern Mediterranean allegedly destroys Alexandria
First Battle of Bull Run [Battle of First Manassas], 1st major battle of the US Civil War is fought near Manassas, Virginia, Confederate victory (US Civil War)
After 13 years, the 4,607-mile Trans-Siberian railway is completed
John T. Scopes found guilty of teaching evolution in the “Scopes monkey trial”, Dayton, Tennessee, fined $100 & costs
Neil Armstrong becomes the first person to step on the Moon at 2:56:15 AM (GMT)
Aswan Dam opens in Egypt, enables human control of the flooding of the Nile
HistoryOrb.com becomes OnThisDay.com
First Crusade: Godfrey of Bouillon is elected the first Defender of the Holy Sepulchre of The Kingdom of Jerusalem.
Battle at Nandorfehervar (Belgrade): Hungarian army under Janos Hunyadi beats Sultan Murad II
First Congress of Vienna settles issues between Poland & Holy Roman Empire - rise of the Habsburgs influence
Warsaw Ghetto Jews (300,000) are sent to Treblinka Extermination Camp
Sarawak achieves independence from British colonial rule
Norway is the victim of twin terror attacks, the first a bomb blast targeting government buildings in central Oslo, second a massacre at a youth camp on island of Utøya
Frederick II crowned King of the Romans (King of the Germans) in Aachen
American William Austin Burt patents "typographer" (typewriter)
Union Act passed by British Parliament, uniting Upper & Lower Canada
Conference of Bretton Woods signed; IMF operations begin
Comet Hale-Bopp is discovered and becomes visible to the naked eye nearly a year later
Jacques Cartier lands in Canada, claims it for France
Benjamin Bonneville leads the first wagon train across the Rocky Mountains by Wyoming's South Pass
American explorer Hiram Bingham discovers Machu Picchu, the Lost City of the Incas
Constantine I is proclaimed Roman Emperor by his troops
English engineer George Stephenson introduces his first steam locomotive, a travelling engine designed for hauling coal on the Killingworth wagonway named Blücher
Benito Mussolini dismissed as Italian Premier and arrested on the authority of King Victor Emmanuel III
World War II: Operation Spring - one of Canada's bloodiest days, 18,444 casualties and 5,021 killed
Scientists announce the first human stem cells to be cultured in a laboratory using tissue taken from aborted human embryos
Battle of Siffin during the first Muslim civil war between Ali ibn Abi Talib and Muawiyah I beside Euphrates River
Francisco Pizarro receives royal charter for the west coast of South America
The Surrey Iron Railway, arguably the world's first public railway, opens in south London.
Vitascope Hall, 1st permanent for-profit movie theatre, opens in New Orleans
United States Attorney General Charles Joseph Bonaparte issues an order to immediately staff the Office of the Chief Examiner (later renamed the Federal Bureau of Investigation).
Declaration of Potsdam: US, Britain and China demand the Japanese surrender during WWII
Fidel Castro leads a failed attack on the Moncada Barracks, intended to spark a revolution in Cuba
Sir Walter Raleigh brings first tobacco to England from Virginia
Battle of Killicrankie: Jacobite Scottish Highlanders under Viscount Dundee defeat royalist force under General MacKay
US Congress establishes Department of Foreign Affairs now referred to as the State Department
Atlantic telegraph cable successfully laid (1,686 miles long)
Frederick Banting and Charles Best isolate insulin at the University of Toronto
French Revolution figure Robespierre & 22 other leaders of "the Terror" guillotined to thunderous cheers in Paris
Austria-Hungary decides against mediation and declares war on Serbia - first declaration of war of WWI
Silent Parade organised by James Weldon Johnson of 10,000 African-Americans who march on 5th Ave in NYC to protest against lynching

The Battle of Gravelines - Spanish Armada damaged & scattered by the English fleet
Irish Potato Famine: Tipperary Revolt - an unsuccessful nationalist revolt against British rule put down by police

US Secretary of State William Howard Taft makes secret agreement with Japanese Prime Minister Katsura agreeing to Japanese free rein in Korea in return for non-interference with the US in the Philippines
Adolf Hitler becomes leader of the National Socialist German Workers Party
Moscow ends the blockade of West Berlin
Frederick I (Barbarossa), Holy Roman Emperor, crowned King of Burgundy

First defenestration of Prague: anti-Catholic Hussites, followers of executed reformer Jan Hus, storm Prague town hall and throw the judge, mayor and several city council members out the windows. They die in the fall or killed by crowd outside.
House of Burgesses Virginia forms, 1st elective American governing body
Indian Wars: Chief Pocatello of the Shoshone tribe signs the Treaty of Box Elder, promising to stop harassing the emigrant trails in southern Idaho and northern Utah.
The Charles, considered the world’s first "oil tanker", departs from the United States headed for Europe with a bulk capacity of 7,000 barrels of oil
1st Penguin book is published, starting the paperback revolution
Pilgrim Fathers depart Leiden for England before heading to America
Politburo enables Operative Order 00447: execute 193,000 Russians
Israel welcomes its one millionth immigrant
Operation Banner, the presence of the British Army in Northern Ireland, and longest-running British Army operation ever, comes to an end.
Justinian I becomes the sole ruler of the Byzantine Empire
Results of the Domesday inquiry presented to William the Conqueror in Salisbury (the date of compilation and the Great Domesday are historically contestable)
Joseph Priestley, English theologian, chemist and author discovers oxygen
Slavery abolished throughout the British Empire - Slavery Abolition Act 1833 comes into effect
Adolf Hitler opens 11th Olympic Games in Berlin
US atomic submarine USS Nautilus begins 1st transit of North Pole "operation Sunshine"
Formal signing of the US Declaration of Independence by 56 people (date most accepted by modern historians)
1st US census conducted, the population was 3,939,214 including 697,624 slaves
Battle of Bad Axe, Wisconsin: 1,300 Illinois militia defeat Sauk & Fox Native Americans ending the Black Hawk War in the US

Marihuana Tax Act of  is passed in America, essentially rendering marijuana and all its by-products illegal
Christopher Columbus sets sail on his first voyage with three ships, Santa María, Pinta and Niña from Palos de la Frontera, Spain for the "Indies"

Battle of Petrovaradin/Peterwardein: Habsburgs under Eugene of Savoy defeat the Turks in a decisive victory
Battle of Mobile Bay, won by the Union Army led by Rear Admiral Farragut with the cry "Damn the torpedoes, full speed ahead!" (US Civil War)
1st electric traffic light installed in the USA on the corner of East 105th Street and Euclid Avenue in Cleveland, Ohio
The Treaty of The Hague is signed whereby the Dutch Republic sells New Holland (Brazil) for 63 tonnes of gold to Portugal
At Auburn Prison in New York, murderer William Kemmler becomes first person to be executed by electric chair
Atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima by the US B-29 Superfortress "Enola Gay"
US President Lyndon B. Johnson signs the Voting Rights Act prohibiting voting discrimination against minorities
Tim Berners-Lee releases files describing his idea for the World Wide Web. WWW debuts as a publicly available service on the Internet.
NASA announces that life may have existed on Mars after examining meteorite ALH84001, thought to be from Mars
Ming Dynasty Chinese military general Cao Qin stages a coup against the Tianshun Emperor
The Battle of Gangut: the first important victory of the Russian Navy during the Great Northern War against Sweden
The Iraqi Government slaughters over 3,000 Assyrians in the village of Sumail. The day becomes known as Assyrian Martyrs Day.
Tokyo Telecommunications Engineering, the precursor to Sony, begins selling its first transistor radios in Japan
Operation Desert Shield begins - US deploys troops to Saudi Arabia
Emperor Krishnadeva Raya is crowned, marking the beginning of the regeneration of the Vijayanagara Empire in Southern India
Venetian senate examines Galileo Galilei's telescope
US Congress adopts silver dollar & decimal system of money
1st national march of Ku Klux Klan (200,000) in Washington, D.C.
USSR establishes a communist government in North Korea
US President Richard Nixon announces he will resign at 12pm the next day
Ceasefire between Iran & Iraq takes effect after 8 years of war
Battle of Adrianople: Goth army defeats Roman forces under Emperor Valens
Robert Gray's Columbia Rediviva returns to Boston after 3 year journey, 1st American ship to circumnavigate the Globe
Rudolf Diesel of Germany patents the diesel internal combustion engine
Mahatma Gandhi & 50 others arrested in Bombay after passing of a "quit India" campaign by the All-India Congress
US drops 2nd atomic bomb "Fat Man" on Japan destroys part of Nagasaki
Singapore separates from the Federation of Malaysia and gains its independence

In Islam, the traditional date of the Laylat al-Qadr, when Muhammad began to receive the Qur'an
John Cabot tells King Henry VII of his trip to "Asia"
King Charles II and John Flamsteed lay the foundation stone of the Royal Observatory in Greenwich, London
US Act of Congress passes establishing the Smithsonian Institution, now world's largest museum and research complex

Allies refuse Japan's surrender offer to retain Emperor Hirohito

NATO takes over command of the peacekeeping force in Afghanistan, marking its first major operation outside Europe in its 54-year-history.
Battle of Didgori: the Georgian army under King David the Builder wins a decisive victory over the famous Seljuk commander Ilghazi

American inventor Isaac Singer patents the sewing machine
Henry Ford's company builds the first Model T car
IBM introduces its first Personal Computer (PC & PC-DOS version 1.0)
Spanish conquistadors under Hernán Cortés capture Aztec Emperor Cuauhtémoc in Tenochtitlan marking the end of the Aztec Empire
Buddhist monks from Kyōto's Enryaku Temple set fire to 21 Nichiren temples throughout Kyoto in the Tenbun Hokke Disturbance. (Traditional Japanese date: July 27, ).
Dutch astronomer Christiaan Huygens discovers Martian south polar cap
Prussia joins Anglo-Dutch alliance to form Triple Alliance to prevent spread of Russo-Swedish War of -90
Second Sino-Japanese War: Japanese forces begin the Battle of Shanghai, a conflict that will last 3 months and involve 1 million troops
During Kublai Khan's Second Invasion of Japan his invading Chinese fleet of 3,500 vessels disappears in a typhoon near Japan
Second Seminole War declared over by Colonel Worth; Indians go on to be removed from Florida to Oklahoma
V-J Day, Japan surrenders unconditionally to end WW II (also August 15 depending on time zone)
Pakistan gains independence from Great Britain
British Army deploys on the streets of Northern Ireland, marking the beginning of Operation Banner
17,000 workers go on strike at the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk, Poland, marking the beginning of the Solidarity movement

Mayflower sets sail from Southampton, England, with 102 Pilgrims

Puyi, the last Chinese Emperor and ruler of Manchukuo is captured by Soviet troops

Usain Bolt sets a new 100 metres world record of 9.69 seconds at the Beijing  Summer Olympics
Wikileaks founder, Julian Assange is granted political asylum by Ecuador
Governor of Roanoke Island colony, John White, returns from England to find no trace of the colonists he had left there 3 years earlier [or Aug 18, 1591]

The Radcliffe Line, the border between Union of India and Dominion of Pakistan is revealed

Monica Lewinsky scandal: US President Bill Clinton admits in taped testimony he had an "improper physical relationship" with the intern and on the same day admits before the nation he "misled people" about the relationship
First public admittance to the Salon de Paris art exhibition at the Louvre in Paris
United States Exploring Expedition headed by Charles Wilkes departs for the Pacific Ocean and Antarctica
US President Woodrow Wilson issues "Proclamation of Neutrality"
Anti-Cigarette League of America forms in Chicago, Illinois

22 year old representative Harry T. Burn is deciding vote in Tennessee's and thus America's ratification of the 19th Amendment to the constitution allowing women's suffrage after letter from his mother
Battle of Britain - 'The hardest day" Luftwaffe lose 69 aircraft, the RAF 68 in largest ever air battle
The Beatles give their 1st public performance at the Kaiserkeller in Hamburg
Details of Louis Daguerre's 1st practical photographic process are released in Paris
World War II: Over 4,000 Canadian and British soldiers killed, wounded or captured raiding Dieppe, France

Conservative members of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union attempt to depose Mikhail Gorbachev in a coup d'état
Operation Iraqi Freedom ends, with the last of the United States brigade combat teams crossing the border to Kuwait
1st Dutch East India Company ships return from the Far East
1st known African Americans in English North America (approx. 20) land at Point Comfort (Fort Monroe), Virginia. They are then sold or traded into servitude.
Alaska first sighted by Danish explorer Vitus Bering at head of Russian expedition

Tchaikovsky's "1812 Overture" opens in Moscow

Minamoto Yoritomo becomes Seii Tai Shōgun and the de facto ruler of Japan. (Traditional Japanese date: July 12, )

American inventor William Seward Burroughs patents the adding machine
"Mona Lisa" stolen from the Louvre by Vincenzo Perugia (Recovered in 1913)
Hawaii becomes the 50th US state

82nd PGA Championship: Tiger Woods become the first golfer since Ben Hogan in 1953 to win 3 majors in a calendar year. He ties the to-par record for the PGA (-18) with Bob May, and wins in a playoff

Madras (now Chennai), India, founded by the British East India Company on sliver of land bought from local Nayak rulers

Battle of Marj Dabiq: Ottoman forces decisively beat the Mamluk Sultanate

Japanese scientist Shibasaburo Kitasato discovers the infectious agent of the bubonic plague and publishes his findings in The Lancet
General Charles de Gaulle walks the Champs Elysees in Paris after the liberation of the city from Nazi occupation

Battle of Crécy, south of Calais in northern France; Edward III's English longbows defeat Philip VI's army, cannons used for first time in battle

British Motor Corporation introduced the Morris Mini-Minor, designed by Alec Issigonis it was only 10 ft long but seated 4 passengers

Battle of Baekgang: Tang Chinese and Silla Korean forces defeat Korean Baekje forces and their Yamato Japanese allies on the Geum River in Korea; - no Japanese invasion of Korea for 900 years

English explorer Henry Hudson, discovers and explores Delaware Bay

1st American built locomotive, "Tom Thumb" races a horse-drawn car from Stockton and Stokes stagecoach company from Baltimore to Ellicott Mills. Let history record that due to mechanical problems the horse won!

Martin Luther King Jr. delivers his "I have a dream speech" addressing civil rights march at Lincoln Memorial, Washington, D.C.

Portugal recognizes the Independence of Brazil

European leaders outlaw crossbow, intending to end war for all time

Beginning of the Battle of Lake Poyang; two Chinese rebel leaders Chen Youliang and Zhu Yuanzhang are pitted against each other in what was one of the largest naval battles in history during Mongol-led Yuan Dynasty
Tokugawa Ieyasu enters Edo Castle (Traditional Japanese date: August 1, )
William Penn leaves England to sail to the New World
Jawaharlal Nehru requests independence of India
Siege of Leningrad by German troops begins during WWII
Possible date for establishment of the Iroquois (Haudenosaunee) League - with the aid of Hiawatha and Deganawidah
The Liberal Party of Australia is founded by Robert Menzies
Federation of Malaya gains independence from Great Britain
The Provisional Irish Republican Army (Sinn Féin) declares a ceasefire in Northern Ireland
Diana, Princess of Wales, dies in a car crash in a road tunnel in Paris
King Louis XIV of France dies after a reign of 72 years—the longest of any major European monarch.
World War II starts as Germany invades Poland by attacking the Free City of Danzig
Jews living in Germany are required to wear a yellow star of David

Colonel Muammar Gaddafi deposes King Idris in the Libyan revolution
Sultan Saladin and King Richard the Lionheart of England sign treaty over Jerusalem, at end of the Third Crusade

Union General William T Sherman captures and burns Atlanta during Savannah Campaign (US Civil War)
Holocaust diarist Anne Frank sent to Auschwitz concentration camp
V-J Day, formal surrender of Japan aboard USS Missouri marks the end of WW II (Japanese date, 1st September in US)
San Marino, one of the smallest nations in the world and the world's oldest republic still in existence, founded by Saint Marinus
Treaty of Paris signed in Paris ends the American Revolutionary War between Great Britain and United States of America

1st Formula One WDC: Giuseppe "Nino" Farina wins by three points

Navigator Henry Hudson first European to discover island of Manhattan [or Sep 11]

11 Israeli athletes taken hostage and later killed by Palestinian Black September group at the Munich Olympics

Mozart's opera "La Clemenza di Tito" premieres in Prague

Word received that American explorer Robert Peary had discovered the North Pole, 5 months earlier

Michelangelo's statue of David is unveiled in Florence
Spanish navigator Juan de Elcano returns to Spain, completing 1st circumnavigation of the globe (expedition began under Ferdinand Magellan)
1st permanent European settlement in the US founded at St. Augustine, Florida
Dutch surrender colony of New Netherlands (including New York) to 300 English soldiers
Black September hijackings begin, three airliners hijacked and blown up by Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine
"The Oprah Winfrey Show" is first broadcast nationally
Battle of Svolder, Baltic Sea. King Olaf on board the Long Serpent defeated in one of the greatest naval battles of the Viking Age.
Congress officially renames the country as the United States of America (Was the United Colonies)
Alexander Twilight, probably first African American to graduate from a US college, receives BA degree at Middlebury College
First fully mechanized unit in the British Army created - the Canadian Automobile Machine Gun Brigade (WWI)
Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization exchange letters of mutual recognition
Queen Elizabeth II becomes Great Britain's longest-reigning monarch at 63 years and seven months, beating the previous record set by her great-great-grandmother, Queen Victoria
George Washington asks for a spy volunteer, Nathan Hale volunteers
Elias Howe takes out a US patent for a lockstich sewing machine
Hamida Djandoubi, convicted of torture and murder, is the last person to be executed by Guillotine in France
The Large Hadron Collider at CERN, described as the biggest scientific experiment in the history of mankind is powered up in Geneva, Switzerland
Battle at Stirling Bridge, Scottish rebel William Wallace beats English
Expulsion order announced against the Moriscos of Valencia; beginning of the expulsion of all Spain's Moriscos
Battle of Zenta: forces of Prince Eugen of Savoye defeat the Turks, ending Ottoman control of large parts of Central Europe

Terrorists hijack a passenger plane and crash it into the Pentagon causing the deaths of 125 people
Attempt by passengers and crew of United Airlines Flight 93 to retake control of their hijacked plane from terrorists causes plane to crash in Pennsylvania field killing all 64 people on board
French astronomer Charles Messier mistakenly identifies the Crab Nebula so begins his Messier Catalogue
World's first patent for synthetic rubber granted to German chemist Fritz Hofmann
Leó Szilárd, waiting for a red light on Southampton Row in Bloomsbury, conceives idea of a nuclear chain reaction
4 teens, following their dog down a hole near Lascaux France discover 17,000-year-old drawings now known as Lascaux Cave Paintings
US Supreme Court orders the all-white Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas to integrate
Luna 2 launched by USSR; 1st spacecraft to impact on the Moon
Church of Holy Sepulchre consecrated in Jerusalem
Francis of Assisi is afflicted with stigmata after a vision praying on Mount Verna
American-Mexican war: US General Winfield Scott captures Mexico City

Public unveiling of the Oslo Accords, an Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement initiated by Norway
George Frideric Handel finishes his "Messiah" oratorio after working on it non-stop for 23 days
Britain (and American colonies) adopt the Gregorian calendar (no Sept 3-Sept 13th)
Napoleon occupies Moscow and the fires start, extinguished by the 19th
World’s 1st practical helicopter, the VS-300 designed by Igor Sikorsky takes (tethered) flight in Stratford, Connecticut
India's Constituent Assembly adopts Hindi as an official language. Celebrated today as Hindi Day.
1st prefrontal lobotomy performed in Washington, D.C.
Iraq, Iran, Kuwait, Saudi-Arabia & Venezuela form Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC)
First non-aristocratic, free public school in Europe is opened in Frascati, Italy
Act of Independence of Central America: Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras & Nicaragua declare their independence from the Spanish Empire
HMS Beagle with Charles Darwin on board reaches the Galapagos Islands
Scottish bacteriologist Alexander Fleming discovers penicillin while studying influenza
Climax of the Battle of Britain, tide turns as Luftwaffe loses 56 aircraft, RAF 28
Google.com is registered as a domain name
British capture Capetown, South Africa, from the Dutch
Mexico issues Grito de Dolores, calling for the end of Spanish rule (Mexican Independence Day)
Slavery abolished in all French territories
Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen discovers the Magnetic South Pole
Federation of Malaysia formed by Malaya, Singapore, British North Borneo (Sabah) and Sarawak
25,000 die in 7.7 earthquake in Tabar, Iran
Apple Computer Inc names co-founder Steve Jobs interim CEO
Arab forces under Amr ibn al-'As conquer Alexandria
Dutch scientist Antonie van Leeuwenhoek is the first to report the existence of bacteria
Battle of Antietam [Battle of Sharpsburg], bloodiest day in the American Civil War 23,110 die in first battle on Union soil
Commonwealth of Australia proclaimed
The Red Baron [Manfred von Richthofen], WWI flying ace of the German Luftstreitkräfte, wins his first aerial combat near Cambrai, France
Anwar Sadat, Menachem Begin and Jimmy Carter sign the Camp David Accords, frameworks for peace in the Middle East and between Egypt and Israel
British expeditionary army conquers Dutch Indies
Great Fire of Moscow burns out after 5 days, 75% of the city destroyed and 12,000 killed
Government bond agent Jay Cooke & Co collapses, causing panic on Wall St, the start of the panic of  and the Long depression
Irish Home Rule bill receives Royal assent
To create a pretext for the invasion of Manchuria, China, a railway explosion is faked by the Japanese
The order for 'extermination asocials through labour' is approved by Otto Thierack, Nazi minister of justice
Mao Zedong's funeral takes place in Beijing
English forces under The Black Prince defeat French at Battle of Poitiers and capture the French King during the Hundred Years War
Siege of Paris by Prussian Forces begins (lasts until January 28 1871)
New Zealand becomes the first country to grant all women the right to vote

US Federal health officials announce AZT will be available to AIDS patients

Spanish expedition led by Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan sets off on the 1st successful circumnavigation of the globe (Magellan killed on route)

In an address to a joint session of Congress and the American people, U.S. President George W. Bush declares a "war on terror".
King James I of England gives Sir Alexander Sterling royal charter for colonisation of Nova Scotia

US President Warren G. Harding signs a joint resolution of approval to establish a Jewish homeland in Palestine

Last people hanged for witchcraft (8) in the US, 20 hanged overall during Salem witch trials

Iraq invades Iran in an attempt to control the Shatt al-Arab waterway
CERN scientists announce their discovery of neutrinos breaking the speed of light
Concordat of Worms agreed between Pope Calixtus II and Holy Roman Emperor Henry V
Fall of Tripolitsa, Greek forces massacre 30,000 Turks during Greek War of Independence
American Herman Hollerith patents his mechanical tabulating machine, the beginning of data processing
Nintendo Koppai (Later Nintendo Company, Limited) founded by Fusajiro Yamauchi to produce and market the playing card game Hanafuda.
The 'Manhattan Project' commences, under the direction of US General Leslie Groves: its aim - to deliver an atomic bomb
Manuel I Komnenos, last Emperor of the Komnenian restoration dies. The Byzantine Empire slips into terminal decline.
US Federal Judiciary Act is passed & creates a six-person Supreme Court
Black Friday; Wall St panic after Gould & Fisk attempt to corner gold
Battle of Shiroyama, decisive victory of the Imperial Japanese Army over the Satsuma Rebellion
"Operation Magic Carpet" sees all Jews from Yemen move to Israel
President Eisenhower orders US troops to desegregate Little Rock schools
Battle of Stamford Bridge; English army under King Harold Godwinson defeat invading Norwegians led by King Harald Hardrada and Harold's brother Tostig, who were both killed

US Congress proposes the Bill of Rights
Leonardo Torres Quevedo successfully demonstrates the Telekino at Bilbao before a great crowd, guiding a boat from the shore, considered the birth of the remote control
First transatlantic telephone cable goes into operation from Newfoundland to Oban
Frances Drake completes circumnavigation of the world, sailing into Plymouth aboard the Golden Hind
Acropolis in Athens attacked by Venetian army trying to eject Turks, damaging the Parthenon
The city council of Amsterdam votes to support William of Orange's invasion of England, which became the Glorious Revolution.
Russia, Prussia and Austria sign the Holy Alliance
Great Britain annexes the Ashanti Kingdom and places it under the governor of the Gold Coast (Ghana)
Beginning of the Meuse-Argonne Offensive, more than 1 million American soldiers in the largest and most costly offensive of WWI
William the Conqueror's troops set sail for England
Earthquake in Gulf of Chili China, reportedly kills 100,000
Society of Jesus (Jesuits) founded by Ignatius Loyola confirmed by Pope Paul III in Rome
John Adams negotiates Revolutionary War peace terms with Great Britain
Mexican revolutionary forces led by Agustín de Iturbide occupy Mexico City as Spanish withdraw, bringing an end to the Mexican War of Independence
French scholar Jean-François Champollion announces that he has deciphered the Rosetta stone
The physics journal Annalen der Physik publishes Albert Einstein's paper "Does the Inertia of a Body Depend Upon Its Energy Content?", introducing the equation E=mc².
Henry Ford's first Ford Model T automobile leaves the Piquette Plant in Detroit, Michigan
Saint Wenceslas is murdered by his brother, Boleslaus I of Bohemia
William the Conqueror invades England landing at Pevensey Bay, Sussex

War of Religion breaks out in France - Huguenots try to kidnap King Charles IX
The first units of the London Metropolitan Police appear on the streets of the British capital
Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 777.68 points, its largest single-day point loss, following the bankruptcies of Lehman Brothers and Washington Mutual
Suleiman the Magnificent succeeds his father Selam I as Ottoman Sultan (rules till 1566)
Anesthetic ether used for 1st time by American dentist Dr William Morton who extracts a tooth
Prussia Minister President Otto von Bismarck's delivers his "Blood & Iron" speech
Treaty of Munich signed by Hitler, Mussolini, Daladier and Chamberlain, forces Czechoslovakia to give territory to Germany
22 Nazi leaders found guilty of war crimes at Nuremberg
Prince Willem III of Orange accepts invitation of take up the British crown
Opening of the Congress of Vienna, redrew Europe's political map after the defeat of Napoléon Bonaparte
Karl Marx' "Das Kapital" published
Henry Ford introduces the Model T car (costs $825)
Muhammad Ali TKOs Joe Frazier in 15 for heavyweight boxing title in "The Thrilla in Manila"

Sultan Saladin captures Jerusalem from Crusaders

George Washington transmits the proposed Constitutional amendments (The United States Bill of Rights) to the States for ratification
"Prelature of the Holy Cross and the Work of God", known as Opus Dei, founded by Saint Josemaría Escrivá

President Roh Moo-hyun of South Korea walks across the Military Demarcation Line into North Korea on his way to the second Inter-Korean Summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong Il

Reunification of East & West Germany. West German flag raised above Brandenburg Gate on the stroke of midnight

WikiLeaks is launched, created by internet activist Julian Assange
Gregorian calendar introduced in Italy and other Catholic countries

French Revolution: Women of Paris march to Versailles in the March on Versailles to confront Louis XVI about his refusal to promulgate the decrees on the abolition of feudalism, demand bread, and have the King and his court moved to Paris
Battle of Thames in Canada; Americans defeat British
Most of Calcutta destroyed by cyclone, approx 60,000 die
Yankees and Giants play an infamous 3-3 tied World Series game

The Beatles release their first record, "Love Me Do"
"Dr. No", 1st James Bond film based on the novel by Ian Fleming and starring Sean Connery and Ursula Andress, premieres in London

Hitler announces plans to regulate Jewish problem

51 Pegasi discovered as the first major star, apart from the Sun, to have a planet orbiting around it

Great standing on the Ugra river, standoff between forces of Akhmat Khan, Khan of the Great Horde, and Ivan III Grand Prince of all Rus, Tataro-Mongols retreat, leds to disintegration of the Horde
The Second Opium War or second Anglo-Chinese War: begins with the Arrow Incident on the Pearl River

The Day of Six Billion: the proclaimed 6 billionth living human in the world is born

Nelson Mandela and South African President F. W. de Klerk awarded the Nobel Peace Prize

World's first soccer club, Sheffield F C, founded in Yorkshire, England

1st trial against nazi war criminals (Nuremberg)

Robert McClure sights the fabled Northwest Passage for the first time (from Banks Island towards Melville Island)

Miner M.de Bruin discovers the infant fossil skull, "Taung child" in a lime quarry in Taung, South Africa. Paleoanthropologist Raymond Dart identifies the fossil as a new hominin species, Australopithecus africanus.

Congress of Vienna opens to re-draw the European political map after the defeat of France, in the Napoleonic Wars.
Vaccine for diphtheria announced by Dr Roux of Paris
Paul Miliukov delivers in the Russian State Duma the famous "stupidity or treason" speech, precipitating the downfall of the Boris Stürmer government.
"Ivy Mike", the first thermonuclear weapon to utilize the H-bomb design of Edward Teller and Stanislaw Ulam, is detonated in the Marshall Islands, Pacific Ocean
Scientists detect evidence of light from the universe's first stars, predicted to have formed 500 million years after the big bang
Verney Cameroon reaches Benguela in Angola, from Africa's east coast, 1st European to cross equatorial Africa

Coronation of Ras Tafari Makonnen as Haile Selassie I, 225th Emperor of Ethopian Solmonic Dynasty

Umar ibn al-Khattab, second Muslim caliph, is killed by a Persian slave in Medina
English parliament accepts Act of Supremacy: Henry VIII becomes Head of Church of England
Great Patent granted to Plymouth Colony
English Long Parliament forms
International Radiotelegraph Conference in Berlin selects "SOS" (· · · – – – · · ·) distress signal as the worldwide standard for help

Eighty Years' War: In Flanders, Spanish defeat Walloon and capture Antwerp
First wagon train arrives in California
Dr Richard Gatling patents Gatling machine gun in Indianapolis
African American inventor Thomas Elkins patents refrigerating apparatus
Howard Carter discovers tomb of Tutankhamun in Egypt
Barack Obama becomes the first African-American to be elected President of the United States
Christopher Columbus learns of maize (corn) from Indians of Cuba
Battle at Panipat: Mogollegers beat hindu leader Hemu

Gunpowder Plot: Catholic conspirator Guy Fawkes attempts to blow up King James I and the British Parliament. Plot discovered, Guy Fawkes caught, tortured and later executed along with seven others. Celebrated ever since as Guy Fawkes Day, where his effigy is traditionally burned on a bonfire, accompanied by fireworks.

Britain and France land airborne forces at Port Said in Egypt, escalating the Suez Crisis

Abraham Lincoln (Rep-R-Ill) elected 16th American President
Mahatma Gandhi arrested for leading Indian miners' march in South Africa

Shah of Iran places Iran under military rule; General Gholan Reza Azhari forms government
Ensisheim Meteorite strikes earth in a wheat field near village of Ensisheim in Alsace, France. Oldest meteorite with a known date of impact

Controversial US presidential election that was later resolved in the Bush v. Gore Supreme Court Case
Roman Emperor Theodosius declares Christian religion the state religion
1st meeting of Moctezuma II & Hernán Cortés in Tenochtitlan, Mexico
William Penn presents Charter of Priviliges

German physicist Wilhelm Röntgen produces and detects electromagnetic radiation in a wavelength range today known as X-rays or Röntgen rays

Family de' Medici become rulers of Florence

Chemical element Darmstadtium discovered at GSI Helmholtz Centre for Heavy Ion Research near Darmstadt, German

st Christmas, according to calendar-maker Dionysus Exiguus
